Abjurating Abjuratives in Abjuration.name: Abjurating Abjuratives in Abjuration
Abjurating Abjuratives in Abjuration.description: "Abjuration is the solemn repudiation, abandonment, or renunciation by or upon oath, often the renunciation of citizenship or some other right or privilege," appears to be written in bold letters on the first page. The following pages contain examples of materials used and the resulting variations of spells. This seems to be a book written by a minstrel, intended to provide a deeper understanding of abjuration and its specific applications in arcane knowledge.

Adder Venom.name: Adder Venom
Adder Venom.description: Adders even if it is a poisonous snake, it is rarely fatal for the regular commoner, however, alchemists do keep them in glass cages to harvest their venom for potions and poisons. Long ago, scales of the snakes were used to create some beautiful egg-shaped bombs - which as we have learned from scrolls - were quite destructive.

Advanced Military Application of the Arc.name: Advanced Military Application of the Arcane Arts
Advanced Military Application of the Arc.description: A small manual that delves into military strategies for the tactical use of arcane arts. It contains multiple chapters covering combat topics such as group formations, flanking techniques, tips for surviving when lost behind enemy lines, essential survival skills, and, in the final chapter, the importance of the chain of command. This manual is issued to newly recruited soldiers, who are expected to memorize all 200 pages of it.

Agate.name: Agate
Agate.description: It is usually found in rocks and comes a variety of amazing colors. Used for millennia in forms of arts and crafts. Based on the region it can have different names or colors. Good common examples are "Fire agate" which is a deep red or "Moss Agate" which has a moss-like appearance and gas a deep green shade.

Agate Ring.name: Agate Ring
Agate Ring.description: The agate ring is rumored to attract wealth and prosperity. This belief may stem from Druidic traditions, which hold that the agate stone shares a strong connection and bond with the surrounding earth. Among the highest class of commoners, however, there exists a strict code of conduct regarding which finger and hand the agate gem should be worn on, a practice that changes depending on the day.

Agave.name: Agave
Agave.description: The agave plant's four major edible parts include flowers, leaves, stalks or basal rosettes, and sap. A beverage is squeezed from baked fibers, and the heads can be baked or boiled, pounded into flat sheets, sun-dried, and stored for future use. The baked, dried heads are also boiled and processed into an edible paste, eaten whole, or incorporated into soups.

Agni Manitite.name: Agni Manitite
Agni Manitite.description: Agni Manitite, also known on the market as Pearl of Fire, is an extremely rare tektite found on select islands. These stones originated from meteorites that collided with large bodies of water, cooling rapidly. This unique formation process makes them exceedingly difficult to recover.

Alabaster.name: Alabaster
Alabaster.description: Alabaster's softness enables it to be carved readily into elaborate forms making it a popular material for carved sculpture. It is also often used for ornamental building work, such as for sculptures, vases, and small decorative carvings.

Albite.name: Albite
Albite.description: Albite is used as a gemstone, albeit semiprecious, and has mainly been use in the manufacturing of glassware. Most potters and glassblowers use this specific gemstone in the manufacturing of glass or ceramics. The completed product is then sold at a premium, as the pure white color of the completed product is quite eye-catching.

Alchemical Brass.name: Alchemical Brass
Alchemical Brass.description: On the rare occasions when Alchemists and Blacksmiths collaborate, they are able to create something truly unique. One such creation is an ingot that can be used to reinforce a weapon, making it so powerful that it can even break mountains when it strikes true. It is said that when Alchemical Brass is added to a regular weapon, it increases the weapon's accuracy and increases the chances of striking vital areas, making the strikes even more fatal.

Alchemist's Counteractant.name: Alchemist's Counteractant
Alchemist's Counteractant.description: More commonly known as Alchemist Bleach, which helps with cleaning or sterilizing surfaces for regular commoners. As it is tricky to do safely, only a few alchemists do actually tackle creating cleaning supplies, and due to it, the price is quite high.

Ale.name: Ale
Ale.description: A beverage similar to beer but without hops, ale contains similar ingredients. The profession of brewster is highly sought after due to the high consumption of ale. Some noble houses purchase and consume nearly 90 gallons of ale daily, not to mention the demand from local taverns and inns.

Alexandrite.name: Alexandrite
Alexandrite.description: It is believed that, if the owner of this transparent gem performs favorable actions or protects his family, he is bestowed with good luck by the gemstone. In some regions, the gemstone is considered sacred and provided as a sacrifice to deities or used to consecrate sites.

Algae.name: Algae
Algae.description: With a consistency similar to quartz and the smoothness of agate, this gem is one of the finest ornamental stones for furniture. According to folklore, it is believed that this gem can prevent the shape-shifting attributes of spells and, in some fringe beliefs, even the living furniture.

Almond.name: Almond
Almond.description: They are sold either raw or roasted. They are also used to produce products like almond milk, oil, butter, flour, paste, or marzipan.

Aluminum Ore.name: Aluminum Ore
Aluminum Ore.description: Aluminum Ore is a lightweight metal used as a material in alloys. Due to its soft nature, blacksmiths use it in combination with silver ore to craft cutlery or containers, while alchemists incorporate it into the creation of certain unique potions.

Amaranth.name: Amaranth
Amaranth.description: Commonly referred to as redroot pigweed, it is primarily used for grain, and then further processed to flour. Due to its quick explosive growth, the three sisters agricultural method is preferred with them, providing a mixture of yields at the moment of harvest.

Amber.name: Amber
Amber.description: Fossilized pine resin, can be polished and used for ornamental purposes such as jewelry beads. There a is high demand for amber by alchemists as it can trap small forgotten creatures.

Amblygonite.name: Amblygonite
Amblygonite.description: Transparent amblygonite, which is the most rare, faceted as a gemstone, is prone to breakage and abrasion when worn in jewelry due to its low hardness and toughness. According to folklore, letting one of these gems dissolve on your tongue is believed to heal internal injuries.

Amethyst.name: Amethyst
Amethyst.description:
"It is said the first Amethyst was a young and beautiful priestess, however, two goddesses fought over her allegiance and unfortunately destroyed her. As the goddesses mourned and wept their loss, their tears combined and created the gem as it fell to the ground. I'm not certain if this tale holds any truth, as I have also heard that an glances and wine was involved." 

Is a very common mineral and is found throughout the realms. It has a beautiful color and is faceted into jewelry cuts, making it one of the most popular gems for collectors.

Anatomy Worksheet.name: Anatomy Worksheet
Anatomy Worksheet.description: Anatomy Worksheet is a specialized sheet that details all the body parts of a creature. From tissues to cranial nerves, from articulations to skeletal muscles, each component is described and drawn in extensive detail to give the reader a full understanding of how the living body functions. The Anatomy Worksheet is used not only for academic study but also for practical applications such as medical treatment, arcane healing, or creature crafting.

Ancient Gold.name: Ancient Gold
Ancient Gold.description: These gold coins can be found in the deepest tombs or burial chambers. Kings or emperors were buried with jars filled with these types of coins. However, untrained adventurers quickly believe that they have the same value as a regular gold coin. Yet, these coins are 100% pure gold, and collectors will pay a high price for any amount of the ancient gold coins located.

Anorthite.name: Anorthite
Anorthite.description: Although anorthite itself is not typically used as a gemstone, some varieties with attractive colors or optical properties may be cut and polished for use in jewelry as a substitute for other, more expensive gemstones. Only the untrained merchant is unable to see the difference between Anorthite and a precious gem, and the purchase of precious rocks is only made by experienced merchants.

Antimony.name: Antimony
Antimony.description: Antimony is quite a bit of a brittle metal. Most lightning-attuned magical users use it as a conductor, a guide for untamed energy coursing through their spells. Alchemists grind antimony into a fine powder to extinguish fires, magical or otherwise. Rarely, the powdered form is used in pigments, valued for its distinctive, eye-catching sparkle.

Antlers.name: Antlers
Antlers.description: Antlers are usually shed and regrown each year by deers, elk, reindeer, or caribous. Due to the replacement nature of the antlers, they can be used to make tools, weapons, ornaments, or even toys. Antler hairdressers are used as a form of leadership by shamans, spiritual figures, and druidic circles. Some forest folk use them as crowns, of different sizes, for their lords, princes, kings, or depending on the case, emperors.

Apatite.name: Apatite
Apatite.description: Apatite is primarily used in the manufacture of fertilizer, dyes, and paint after being ground into fine dust. On rare occasions it is cut into a gem, it is a soft stone that can be easily worked by gem cutters without the need for specialized tools or extensive experience.

Aphid.name: Aphid
Aphid.description: Aphids are tiny insects that survive by sucking sap from plants. Their presence can lead to serious crop damage, and without intervention, they pose a threat to farms, trees, and gardens alike. Commoners dread any appearance of this little critters.

Apple.name: Apple
Apple.description: Apples are grown almost in all regions and they are usually eaten raw, however, they can also be used in different dishes mainly pies, or in alcohol fermentation for ales or local ciders.

Apricot.name: Apricot
Apricot.description: One of the few fruits that is also dried, to have it be edible between seasons. It is also used in various meals, summer salads, jams, juices, and even alcohol after boiling.

Aquamarine.name: Aquamarine
Aquamarine.description: Aquamarine is one the most popular light-blue gemstone and is extensively used in jewelry. Rings, earrings, and bracelets are made from Aquamarine, and it is especially important as a pendant stone, with fairly large pendants being faceted. It is also believed, that it was at some point a spell component for a rare and secret spell.

Aradite.name: Aradite
Aradite.description: Aradite gemstone has the unique ability to glow in the dark, making it a popular light source for many underground civilizations. Alongside Neon-Ront, it is frequently used due to its abundance.

Aragonite.name: Aragonite
Aragonite.description: Aragonite is one of the most challenging gemstones to cut, requiring the expertise of a highly skilled gemstone cutter to shape it into ornamental stones. There are rumors that these stones can interfere with magical items when in close proximity, but such claims are generally considered unfounded.

Archery Target.name: Archery Target
Archery Target.description: Originally, archery targets were simple mounds of earth, but skilled archers quickly wore them down by hitting the same spots repeatedly. To solve this, wooden archery targets were developed, made primarily of hardwood and reinforced with heavy rope and straw to handle the high amount of arrows. Wealthier archers could afford targets with colored paper, marked in red, blue, and black to create the famous bullseye design.

Arpa Doppia.name: Arpa Doppia
Arpa Doppia.description: The Arpa Doppia, or double harp, renowned for its intricate double strings, delivers a one-of-a-kind sound, cherished by the upper high-class members of society and frequently gracing the vibrant, bustling cities across the realms.

Artichoke.name: Artichoke
Artichoke.description: The leaves of the artichoke are typically removed one by one, and the fleshy base is enjoyed with vinaigrette, vinegar, butter, mayonnaise, aioli, lemon juice, or other sauces. Stuffed or boiled artichokes come in numerous variations, with a common stuffing featuring breadcrumbs, garlic, oregano, parsley, grated cheese, and sausage.

Asparagus.name: Asparagus
Asparagus.description: It is sometimes also named Sparrow Grass, its young shoots are often used as a spring vegetable. They are usually served as an appetizer or a vegetable side dish. In some regions, there is word of a festival held in its honor.

Aspen Log.name: Aspen Log
Aspen Log.description: Aspen wood is white, soft, lightweight, and fairly strong and has a multitude of uses. Mainly found in colder climates, making it one of the more widespread trees. Its bark is used in multiple medicinal poultices by herbalists mainly for its antioxidants or anti-inflammatory properties.

Aspen Lumber.name: Aspen Lumber
Aspen Lumber.description: Aspen Lumber is a wood that is soft but fairly strong, and it is closest to white in color. It has a fine-grained, uniform texture and lacks a distinctive pattern. Due to its light color, it is perfect for making paper, matchsticks, furniture, doors, and window frames.

Assaying Tool.name: Assaying Tool
Assaying Tool.description: It is commonly known as a Touchstone, a tool made from slate with a finely-grained surface on which metals leave a small trace. The touchstone is used by merchants and bank tellers along with equivalent metal leaves to identify the purity of coins, bars, or jewelry. The metal leaves, made of gold, silver, platinum, or electrum with various purity levels, are scratched on the touchstone along with the soon-to-be-acquired metal to determine its purity or whether it is a counterfeit.

Augelite.name: Augelite
Augelite.description: Augelite is an ornamental stone found throughout the realms. It is mainly worn by priests and is embedded into jewelry and holy symbols. This gemstone is stated to reflect any magic, or it is rarely used to create small anti-magic fields. Commoners claim that augelite gemstone has the ability to absorb negative energy and its widely believed that this is the reason is embedded in religious items.

Aurichalcum Coin.name: Aurichalcum Coin
Aurichalcum Coin.description: Aurichalcum Coins once saw widespread circulation in ancient times. However, in the more recent era, they are found only in remote regions with scarce access to primary metals such as gold or silver, where they are valued similarly to gold pieces.

Aurichalcum Ingot.name: Aurichalcum Ingot
Aurichalcum Ingot.description: When impurities are removed and clear ingots are produced, Aurichalcum Ingots finds several uses in essential components such as gears, ship parts, impellers, bearings, metallic sleeves, and other mechanical parts. Aurichalcum also remains tied to its ancient roots, with coins being minted to continue this long-standing tradition.

Aurichalcum Ore.name: Aurichalcum Ore
Aurichalcum Ore.description: Deep within the veins of the earth lies Aurichalcum, an alloy of zinc and copper, shimmering like brass yet valued as highly as gold. In the rarest of conditions, where pressure mounts and time stretches endlessly, this alloy crystallizes into Aurichalcite. Coins forged from Aurichalcum were considered treasures of great worth, symbolizing prosperity and power in societies long past.

Aventurine.name: Aventurine
Aventurine.description: While green is the most common color of aventurine, it can also appear in shades of orange, brown, yellow, blue, or grey. Aventurine finds use in diverse applications such as landscape and building stones, aquarium decorations, monuments, and jewelry.

Avocado.name: Avocado
Avocado.description: There have been found many uses for the avocado fruit, ranging from treating ailments to culinary purposes. Sometimes it is cut into thin slices or made into a paste, which is said it provides a glow to your skin. Herbalists are a bit uncertain about its cosmetic use, however, according to them, consumption is rather safe.

Axinite.name: Axinite
Axinite.description: Axinite gemstones have the misfortune of being brown, a color not in high demand for gemstones. Despite this, they are often used in rings because they can maintain a sharp edge and endure the rough and tumble of a tavern brawl. This has earned them the nickname "knuckle stones".

Azurite.name: Azurite
Azurite.description: Azurite is a very popular mineral in an azure-blue color and is usually cut into beads or ornamental objects. Due to its resistance to fire, most of the time it is used by blacksmiths as a lucky charm to avoid injury while working.

Balista.name: Balista
Balista.description: Ballista is a weapon that is used mainly for fort and settlement defense. It relies on different mechanics than a regular crossbow, using two levers with torsion springs instead of a tension prod. There are some rumors that a more advanced weapon exists called a polybolos, however, these rumors remain unfounded.

Bamboula.name: Bamboula
Bamboula.description: The bamboula, a drum made from a rum barrel covered with skin on one end, is also associated with a traditional dance that shares its name. In communities that embrace the bamboula, its music and dance foster an exceptionally close-knit spirit. While the instrument is common in island nations, it's not unusual for traveling bards or historians to encounter it outside those regions.

Banana.name: Banana
Banana.description: A fruit favored by most folk, herbalists recommend it if your stomach is upset, innkeepers provide it mushed as sweet beverages, and commoners eat it raw as it is quite tasty.

Bark Tanned Hide.name: Bark Tanned Hide
Bark Tanned Hide.description: While some hides, after harvesting, are used as is in processing, some of them go through an extra step, mainly to have a specific color. In a liquid concoction of multiple types of oil, with a specific tree bark, they are left to soak for several weeks prior to processing into leather. The overall process is not known by many leatherworkers, and sometimes confused with tannin, however, for those who know and use it in their work, it does fetch them an extra coin, as the end result color tends to be quite unique.

Barrel.name: Barrel
Barrel.description: Barrels are among the most widely used storage containers, especially for liquids. Their uses range from fermenting strong alcohols to preserving pickled foods or storing homemade juices, making them the preferred choice for high-capacity storage.

Basalt Stone.name: Basalt Stone
Basalt Stone.description: The basalt rock comes mainly in a dark-gray color and is used in construction for building blocks or in the groundwork, or cobblestones and in making statues by famous masons.

Basil.name: Basil
Basil.description: A common spice used in cuisines throughout the realms. It's speculated that it soothes and cures the heart when consumed. However, no herbalists have confirmed any curing proprieties of basil. It is often used by commoners.

Bay Leaf.name: Bay Leaf
Bay Leaf.description: The bay leaf is an aromatic leaf frequently used as a herb in cooking. It imparts a subtle, herbal flavor to dishes and can be used whole, either dried or fresh. Typically, it is removed from the dish before consumption. Bay leaves can also be used in ground form, though this is less common.

Bean Soup.name: Bean Soup
Bean Soup.description: The bean soup is a very hearty meal with beans, veggies for garnish, and meats. In some more distinctive places, it is served in a bread bowl or with a few slices of bread.

Bean Stew with Meat.name: Bean Stew with Meat
Bean Stew with Meat.description: Large quantities of smoked meats are prepared in advance, as they are a key ingredient in most bean stews. In a cast iron oven over a fire, all the ingredients, including the smoked meat, are added and cooked over a slow flame, and they are served with a spicy pepper as a side.

Beans.name: Beans
Beans.description: They come in all colors; from green to red, to black to white, preferred by commoners and tavern keeps as they are quite filling when cooked, as well as, the fact that farming them is not as demanding as other vegetables.

Bear Hide.name: Bear Hide
Bear Hide.description: While generalized as a bear hide for simplicity, it usually includes more than just the regular for a legged creature, it is usually referred to by size. Some rumors mention one that is a bit on the weirder territory, a pelt associated with what some call a mythical animal, while others swear on their life it is real, that is filled with owl feathers.

Bear's Trace.name: Bear's Trace
Bear's Trace.description: The Gleaming Unicorn and Golden Deer coins are considered valuable by some, but woodland folk refuse to touch them due to their metal properties. To create an alternative, the folk imbue a piece of soil with magic, and each minter uses their own animal form paw, claw, or hoof to create a unique mark in the mold as a signature. These coins have a value close to a copper due to their magical imbue, and multiple forgeries have been attempted. However, those familiar with the arcane arts can realize the coin is a counterfeit, or simply by adding water, as the coin is made of soil and it simply gets muddy. The magical imbuement also gives the coins water-repelling properties, making them harder to counterfeit.

Bearberry.name: Bearberry
Bearberry.description: A lot of gatherers, herbalists, and alchemists grow Bearberries around their workplaces, as it is assumed that they attract bees and hummingbirds, to help with pollination and honey, and butterflies to harvest their wings. The Bearberry fruit is used very loosely in medicine, mainly in medicinal teas. Bearberries are also used by Leatherworkers as a tanning agent to turn hides into leather.

Bedside Chest.name: Bedside Chest
Bedside Chest.description: For the commoners who cannot afford a bedside dresser or wardrobe, a Bedside Chest offers a cost-effective alternative for storing all forms of clothing.

Beer.name: Beer
Beer.description: Most taverns, pubs, and monasteries brew their own beers to meet local demand. Since beer is inexpensive to produce in large quantities, it consistently provides a steady profit for these establishments.

Beet.name: Beet
Beet.description: It is sometimes referred to as beetroot. It is rumored that red beetroot is used in potions that boost the vitality of the consumer, thought to be used specifically because of its red color, however, these rumors are unfounded. Herbalists and alchemists do use them in potions, not for their coloring properties but for the health benefits they provide.

Belajurite.name: Belajurite
Belajurite.description: Lost to history, this gem is known from only a handful of discovered specimens. No one alive knows its exact appearance. Descriptions from ancient scrolls suggest it was a deep seawater green gem with a smooth surface, and all known specimens were approximately the size of a human fist.

Belladonna Fruit.name: Belladonna Fruit
Belladonna Fruit.description: Belladonna Fruit is one of the most toxic fruits known throughout the realms. As such, it is only farmed and harvested by the most skilled Gatherers. Without the proper expertise and knowledge, inexperienced folks might be fooled into eating the cherry-like fruit. After being processed, it is sometimes used in cosmetics as its effects are considered to have an attractive and seductive quality. When a solution is dropped in the eyes it dilates the pupils. The plant has multiple applications, however, its main usage is to create very potent poisons. It is speculated even Emperors have fallen to it.

Bench.name: Bench
Bench.description: Wooden benches are frequently used in outdoor terraces and busy taverns due to their ability to seat multiple people. Usually purchased in bulk as they have a limited lifespan due to constant use.

Benitoite.name: Benitoite
Benitoite.description: Benitoite crystals are known for their relative softness and are often found as fragments rather than intact crystals. They were commonly used as inlays for coffers, ornamental boxes, and statuettes.

Berimbau.name: Berimbau
Berimbau.description: Resembling a wooden hunting bow, the instrument comprises the verga referred to as the bow, a steel string, and a dried, hollowed calabash attached to its lower end. It is most commonly played by martial artists who practice capoeira. This distinctive fighting style integrates music and dance as part of its movements.

Birch Log.name: Birch Log
Birch Log.description: The Birch Log is a common yet essential item within the realms, prized for its versatility and utility. It is a thin, pale log harvested from the birch trees that grow in abundance throughout the land. The wood is strong yet pliable, making it perfect for a wide variety of uses. Craftsmen and artisans alike value the Birch Log for its ability to be shaped and molded into a wide range of objects. It is often used to create everything from simple tools and household items to intricate carvings and intricate pieces of furniture.

Birch Plank.name: Birch Plank
Birch Plank.description: The plank is incredibly strong and durable, yet surprisingly light and easy to work with. It is the perfect material for creating everything from delicate jewelry and intricate carvings to elegant furniture and powerful artifacts. Most towns' sawmills that trade in it, are speculated to have highly skilled craftsmen and artisans in their midst.

Bismuth Bronze.name: Bismuth Bronze
Bismuth Bronze.description: Bismuth Bronze or Bismuth Brass is a copper alloy primarily used for manufacturing corrosion-resistant bolts, nails, and various other metal components. Its unique properties make it a favored choice for marine environments.

Bitterroot.name: Bitterroot
Bitterroot.description: Bitterroot is a plant that is prized for its beautiful flowers, which come in a range of colors and can survive in most climates. However, it is not the flowers that are in demand, but the roots of the plant. Bitterroot roots are considered a delicacy and are widely sought after. Some people believe that consuming bitterroot before a journey will help to keep wild beasts at bay.

Black Pearl.name: Black Pearl
Black Pearl.description: Called the Black Pearl only as a descriptor factor, for it is known that it's possible to dye the pearl to achieve this specific dark color. In some religions, it is believed that if these pearls are found, they show the deity's favor or disfavor based on circumstance

Black Sapphire.name: Black Sapphire
Black Sapphire.description: Mainly called Star Sapphire, when cut into shape, the reflection of the gem forms into a distinct, six-rayed star. Its magical proprieties have been almost forgotten these days, but it is assumed that its magic involves the passage of time and the ability to control it.

Blackberries.name: Blackberries
Blackberries.description: It is usually a favorite fruit for making desserts, wines, and even liqueurs. Medicinally it is often used by herbalists to reduce bleeding, or as a cosmetic to make the skin less oily.

Blacksmith's Ring.name: Blacksmith's Ring
Blacksmith's Ring.description: After finalizing their training, newly appointed blacksmiths face one final challenge, the creation of the Blacksmith’s Ring. This task is more than ceremonial, as it marks the transition from a new apprentice to a skilled artisan. The ring itself is a solid iron band, engraved with the blacksmith’s family seal. The material, iron, chosen deliberately for its difficulty in delicate shaping and detailed engraving. It serves as one final lesson, as even the most unyielding material can be shaped into something precise, personal, and enduring.

Blewits.name: Blewits
Blewits.description: Blewits are strong and delicious mushrooms, quickly identified by their faint purple coloring. Look for them in the fall in mulch piles, and sauté them for dinner. Quite often they are mistaken for a different mushroom called "Amethyst Deceiver", however, both are edible.

Blood Potion.name: Blood Potion
Blood Potion.description: Every year in the shadowed weeks of the Red Harvest, when the fields lie fallow and folk light lanterns carved from turnips, you’ll find barrels of blood potion hauled out from cellars and cellared caves. Despite its name, there’s not a drop of true blood in the drink. It’s a thick, jewel-red brew made from cherries or dark forest berries, boiled down into a syrupy kompot and spiced with cloves, cinnamon bark, and sometimes a splash of vinegar to give it a bite sharp enough to wake the dead.

Bloodstone.name: Bloodstone
Bloodstone.description: A dark-colored gemstone with small speckles of red or brown spots, on occasion these can also look similar to stripes or veins. It's mainly used as a seal stone for stone flooring or used in ornate small carvings or figures, and other proprieties include its use as a medicinal agent. If placed on an open wound it helps the blood coagulate faster.

Blue Quartz.name: Blue Quartz
Blue Quartz.description: Preferred by glassmiths or gaffers, to make different types of cups and vases and with help from the blacksmiths it is used to ornate tankards. Magic wielders use this gemstone to see across the lands or through someone's deceit.

Blue Sapphire.name: Blue Sapphire
Blue Sapphire.description: Fine-colored Sapphire with a deep blue color and excellent transparency can reach several hundreds of gold coins per stone. One of the most used items in magical spells that involve affecting the mind. In some regions it is used in creating magical mechanical constructs like golems.

Blue-White Diamond.name: Blue-White Diamond
Blue-White Diamond.description: The most notable gem from the Diamond variations is usually the colorless one which does have a blue white tint. The use of diamond is mainly on the jewelry market. Due to its brilliance, hardness, and rarity, it is the most famous of all gemstones.

Blueberry.name: Blueberry
Blueberry.description: Most folks collect large quantities of blueberries to be eaten raw or dried for later use. Dried berries were added whole to puddings and cakes or ground and added to flour, soups, and meat as flavoring. Blueberries were also commonly mixed with dry, ground meat to make pemmican.

Boar Cranium.name: Boar Cranium
Boar Cranium.description: The boar, in more traditional regions, represents good health and incredible strength. As most cannot afford the price of a taxidermist to have the head mounted on a wall, an alternative is to obtain the skull directly, as it is quite easy to acquire and a favored decoration in some country homes.

Boiled Corn.name: Boiled Corn
Boiled Corn.description: Young corn, before it fully matures, can be grilled or boiled with salt. This seasonal delicacy is available only before the corn's harvest and for a very limited time. It tends to be in high demand due to its delicious timed flavor.

Bolt.name: Bolt
Bolt.description: Bolts, nuts, and screws are indispensable in various aspects of life, serving roles in the construction of tools, locks, clocks, furniture, and even in fastening together robust pieces of metal equipment. Noble individuals, particularly those clad in heavy-wearing armor, often retain the services of a dedicated armorer who accompanies them at all times. This skilled armorer carries essential tools of the trade, including a hammer, replacement bolts, wire cutter, and nail puller, ensuring that the noble's armor remains in optimal condition wherever their journey takes them.

Bone Dice.name: Bone Dice
Bone Dice.description: Made from most creatures, mainly ankle bones from animals or otherwise, however, hooves, horns, and even antlers were also used. In the past the dice were not used for games, were used by religious figures with rocks, sticks, or even animal entrails, for fortune-telling. In some of the more remote regions playing dice might be an insult and is advisable against it.

Bone Drinking Glass.name: Bone Drinking Glass
Bone Drinking Glass.description: Some of the more eccentric folks look to fill their cupboards with plates, cups, or glasses made out of bone, or with bone paraphernalia embossed on them. Due to the nature of most of the materials procured that are needed to produce kitchenware, they tend to come at a very high trade value. Yet, not a lot of crafters can manipulate bone into usable items, making the rarity even more pronounced.

Book of Fables.name: Book of Fables
Book of Fables.description: A series of fantastical stories written by multiple authors. Young readers hold a few of these tales dear to their hearts, particularly the animal-centered ones, one which follows a rabbit and a turtle and another tells of a fox trying to reach some grapes.

Book of Pawns.name: Book of Pawns
Book of Pawns.description: "Book of Pawns" is a humorously named tome containing a collection of puns designed to make even the most stoic individuals groan. Some prime examples include: "What happens if you ask a treant for life advice? He’ll tell you to branch out and leave." or "Why did the kobold’s stand-up act bomb? - Their jokes drag on."

Box of Horrors.name: Box of Horrors
Box of Horrors.description: They appear only during Red Harvest, when the nights grow long and the air stinks of smoke and cider. Children wait all year for them, as they are filled to the brim with sweets, darting between bonfires with sticky fingers and purple-stained lips. Grown traders pretend they’re above such things, though I’ve seen more than one caravan master “inspect” an entire box before camp is set.

Braided Bread.name: Braided Bread
Braided Bread.description: A traditional food in many places, its symbolism varies greatly by region. In some areas, it is associated with the loss of a loved one, where a loaf of braided bread is placed at the burial site to symbolize a connection in the other realms. In others, it represents the union of two newlyweds, with the braids symbolizing intertwined arms and love. While in other regions, it holds no cultural significance.

Brain.name: Brain
Brain.description: They’re said to come from… well, that’s the tricky part. A few merchants claim they’re harvested after accidents or battles, yet others swear it’s some artisan’s grisly craft, pressed and preserved with secret oils. I can’t say which is true, but either way, they’re fragile. Keep it away from sunlight and rough hands.

Brass.name: Brass
Brass.description: Brass is similar to bronze, another alloy containing Copper and Tin. Brass is quite a popular material for decoration due to its bright gold appearance. Its usage ranges from locks, hinges, and gears to plumbing and valves, as well as in the creation of instruments like horns or bells.

Bread.name: Bread
Bread.description: Bread is a staple food made from dough that has been baked. It comes in a variety of shapes, sizes, and flavors. It is often sold as a side in most taverns and inns for any of the main meals they serve.

Bread Buns.name: Bread Buns
Bread Buns.description: Bread buns are also referred to as bread rolls, commonly cut and filled to make a wide array of sandwiches. Most places offer them as a side for stews or soups.

Breadseed Poppy.name: Breadseed Poppy
Breadseed Poppy.description: The breadseed poppy is a decorative plant often found in gardens. It is grown for its seeds, oil, and medicinal properties. When combined with strong alcohol, it can be used as a powerful pain reliever.

Breathing Aparatus.name: Breathing Aparatus
Breathing Aparatus.description: This mechanized device created for the sole purpose of assisting with relaxing hobbies, such as diving, but also useful in the deepest mines where breathing is a luxury. Primarily made out of copper to avoid rust, the device is quite heavy due to its material, and only trained professionals are advised to use it.

Brined Cheese.name: Brined Cheese
Brined Cheese.description: Commonly known as akkawi, halloumi, feta, or telemea, this cheese is common and popular across different regions. Its brined process makes it perfect for salads, grilling, and traditional dishes throughout the realms.

Broadcloth.name: Broadcloth
Broadcloth.description: The most common type of cloth, it is usually referred to as plain cloth. Traditionally used in any form of clothing, as well, as for interior decoration, such as tablecloths, curtains, and wall covers.

Brocade.name: Brocade
Brocade.description: The life of a noble is filled with entertainment, riding, hunting, music, and dancing, all of these activities are a stage for the display of fashion. Wealthy nobles wear brocade-type clothing, they are made with multi-colored silks and sometimes even embedded with gold and silver threads, as a display of wealth.

Broccoli.name: Broccoli
Broccoli.description: A plant from the cabbage family, it usually comes in green, purple, or white hues. Mainly cooked boiled, however, steaming, roasting and stir-frying are also tasty options.

Bronze Gunmetal.name: Bronze Gunmetal
Bronze Gunmetal.description: Bronze Gunmetal is an alloy of copper, tin, and zinc, with trace amounts of other metals such as lead or nickel, found its primary use in casting cannons, firearms, and various military equipment but also in fittings, gears, bearings, statues, and small objects such as buttons.

Brooch.name: Brooch
Brooch.description: Brooch is a decorative jewelry item designed to be attached to garments, to fasten them together. It is usually made of metal, silver or gold or some other material, like clay. Brooches are frequently decorated with silver strands or with gemstones and may be solely for ornament and it can also serve a function as a clothes fastener.

Brotherhood of the North.name: Brotherhood of the North
Brotherhood of the North.description: Identified as a historical book, most of its contents have yet to be fully translated. Historians, with each revision, attempt to update the book with their latest findings, however, it appears to be written in an extinct language from millennia ago. From the currently available translations, the text seems to consist mostly of poems describing battles for Nordic territories. Yet, even these interpretations are heavily debated, as the accuracy of the translations remains uncertain.

Bucket.name: Bucket
Bucket.description: While buckets are commonly used to transport water from wells to homes or for cleaning tasks, they can also be repurposed as makeshift latrines in extreme situations or certain jail cells where outhouses are not an option.

Buckle.name: Buckle
Buckle.description: Leatherworkers usually order these in large quantities, as they go on several pieces of gear, for both adventurers and commoners alike. Some of their additions are in purses, bags, backpacks, belts, armors, epaulets, shoes, and many more. They are primarily made out of iron or steel and poured into molds.

Burger.name: Burger
Burger.description: A burger is made by grilling a patty of ground beef and placing it between two halves of a bun. Additional ingredients like raw onion slices, lettuce, bacon, and mayonnaise can be added to enhance the flavor.

Butter.name: Butter
Butter.description: This classic dairy product, made by churning cream, is an essential ingredient in sweet and savory recipes. Used for its fat in baking, sauces, frying, or simply spread on warm toast, butter makes any dish taste amazing.

Button Mushroom.name: Button Mushroom
Button Mushroom.description: A type of mushroom that can be found easily in the forest, due to their clear white color, or distinctive brown. They are also sometimes referred to as the chestnut mushrooms, due to their coloring matching the chestnut trees. It is mainly used for a wide range of culinary dishes, ranging from, stews, salads, soups, and many others.

Byrne.name: Byrne
Byrne.description: These belts were typically made from leather, woven braid, embroidered fabric or solid metalwork. Commoner women favored sturdier and more practical versions made from leather or tightly woven wool, as they mostly used them as a stand-in for a corset. Most belts remained plain apart from the buckle, while men often chose theirs to display status and personal pride.

Cabbage.name: Cabbage
Cabbage.description: The main ingredient in most salads and stews, it is usually, in high demand by inns and taverns for the dinners of their patrons. Most home farms have a few cabbage heads planted around, and it's very commonly preserved in salt for use over the winter in the form of sauerkraut.

Cacoxenite.name: Cacoxenite
Cacoxenite.description: Cacoxenite is more commonly associated with iron ores than with gemstones; however, due to its unnatural shine of gold, orange, or deep red, it can also be used by jewelers for intricate and colorful jewelry, as well as by blacksmiths to create beautifully crafted armaments.

Cake.name: Cake
Cake.description: Cake is a baked dessert made from a mixture of flour, sugar, and other ingredients. In their earliest forms, cakes were variations of bread, but today they come in a wide range of preparations that can be simple or elaborate. Bakeries usually make cakes to order for events such as anniversaries, weddings, or birthdays. Depending on the situation, the process of making a cake can be complex and time-consuming, taking anywhere from a few hours to in rare occasions close to a day. Cakes can contain fresh fruits, jams, milk, and can even be soaked in juice for additional flavor. In most cases, the cake is covered in cold sweetened cream and decorated with additional fruits or other toppings.

Calamine.name: Calamine
Calamine.description: Calamine is an uncommon gemstone and typically exhibits a semi-transparent bluish-green color with beautiful luster. Widely believed in remote regions of the world that if you place a small shard of this specific gem directly on top of someones eye as a lens, over time, it is believed that it can restore the eyesight.

Calendar.name: Calendar
Calendar.description: Simple tracker for the days of multiple seasons, clearly indicated by symbols or drawings, allows regular commoners to easily track what specific date it is in the current season and how long is left until the end. This can be used to track specific events like harvest, spring, or any other festivals.

Calico Bass.name: Calico Bass
Calico Bass.description: Calico Bass, often called kelp bass or bull bass, is an easily caught fish, lured in by small bait like worms, minnows, or plankton. With many uses in cooking, it is great for many dishes. Still, it is most frequently enjoyed grilled or wrapped in flavorful tacos.

Caltabose.name: Caltabose
Caltabose.description: The Caltabose sausage is primarily made of pork meat, but unlike regular sausages, it uses multiple types of pork cuts, including liver, kidney, pork belly, rind, and spleen, along with rice, onions, and spices.

Canary Diamond.name: Canary Diamond
Canary Diamond.description:
"In the past, diamonds were used for a form of magic called gemstone magic, the casters would call upon the spell into the diamond to be used at a later time. This has been replaced with magical scrolls nowadays as it is more cost-effective. Depending on the spell you implement certain triggers, and create some very specific and intricate traps, which is not achievable with regular spell scrolls. That knowledge as interesting as it was, is lost to time." 

 

A deep yellow diamond, one of the most expensive variants, is usually close to double in price of its regular non-colored counterpart.

Cannon.name: Cannon
Cannon.description: Unlike the ballista, cannons are designed for offensive use, largely because they are mounted on wheels. These wheels serve multiple purposes, they make the cannon easier to transport by sea or road and absorb the force of its powerful recoil. Earlier models of cannons without wheels often had a habit of shattering due to the recoil.

Cantaloupe.name: Cantaloupe
Cantaloupe.description: Cantaloupes are often eaten as a refreshing and hydrating snack, and they can also be used in a variety of dishes and recipes, such as salads, juices, and pies. They come in a variety of colors ranging from white, to green, to orange, to red.

Capricia Verde.name: Capricia Verde
Capricia Verde.description: Capricia Verde is a strong brew with rum, and usually, orange, orange leaves, and cinnamon. Regardless of its ingredients, Capricia Verde is a symbol of camaraderie. Sailors often pass around mugs of it during celebrations, farewells, or after surviving storms, placing it as a ritual of shared unity and fellowship.

Carambola.name: Carambola
Carambola.description: Carambola is fleshy, crunchy, juicy, slightly tart, acidic, and sweet in taste. It is star-shaped and golden-yellow in appearance and is frequently used in the preparation of fruit salads and fruit platters, as a garnish in cocktails and beverages, or squeezed into a juice and served as a functional beverage.

Carbon Steel.name: Carbon Steel
Carbon Steel.description: Commonly mistaken for dark steel due to its similar coloring but lacking its arcane properties, this alloy is a very strong variant of steel. However, it is more prone to rusting. It is primarily used to create cutting tools, springs, wrenches, hammers, and other types of tools used in construction.

Carbuncle.name: Carbuncle
Carbuncle.description: Also known as Red Garnet, is one of the most affordable gemstones used in all types of jewelry. It is believed that if its mounted and enchanted on a weapon the strike with the weapon will kill any enemy.

Carnation.name: Carnation
Carnation.description: Commonly known as Carnation or Clove Pink, and besides the ornamental aspect of them, where most houses have a potted flower. The Carnations, after turning in a paste with honey, are used by some herbalists to treat issues such as skin problems, hair loss, and muscle tension.

Carnelian.name: Carnelian
Carnelian.description: Rarely referred to as Sard. It is stated that when wearing this gemstone, you can feel Lady Luck smile upon you. When cut, it is used as beads for necklaces or bracelets, rarely used as large slabs, as designs carved out for portraits or busts.

Carp Steak.name: Carp Steak
Carp Steak.description: Imagine a fresh-cut carp steak sizzling on the grill, the smoky aroma mixing with herbs and spices, or a baked fillet coming out of the oven golden brown, ready to be served with a side of roasted vegetables and a splash of lemon. This is the essence of carp: simple yet delicious, prepared fresh for every meal.

Carpenters Plane.name: Carpenters Plane
Carpenters Plane.description: A plane, featuring a cleverly hafted cutting edge, is meticulously designed to skin or shave the surface of wood. Employed for finishing and leveling surfaces, it adeptly erases marks left by earlier tools such as an ax, hammer, or saw, leaving the wood smooth, flat, and straight

Carpet Beetle.name: Carpet Beetle
Carpet Beetle.description: Carpet Beetles are almost everywhere, and it is likely that every farmer hearth has a few. As scavengers, they consume dead insects, fur, hair, skin, and other decaying organic matter. They pose no threat to living beings and neither bite nor sting, in the more abstract sciences, herbalists tend to use them to estimate the time of death.

Carriage Safety Guide.name: Carriage Safety Guide
Carriage Safety Guide.description:
Small safety scroll that contains information of the next carriage trip, with points such as:

  • Smoking Area: While we acknowledge the confusion, this area is not intended for the consumption of exotic herbs. It is specifically designated for humanoids of elemental nature. Please refrain from any form of extinguishing in this area.

  • Metal, Heavy, and Large Creatures: If you are a creature composed of metal, of significant size, or a magic user who carries extensive inventory in compact spaces (e.g., extra-dimensional storage), please inform us prior to boarding. Specialized equines may be required. Failure to notify us will result in extended baggage fees.

  • Clawed Humanoids: Please refrain from scratching any seats or wooden parts of the carriage.

  • Horned Humanoids: Horned individuals must keep their horns corked at all times unless their horns curve inward toward themselves.

  • Transmutation Casters: Do not transmute any liquids into alcohol. Following a previous incident, all alcohol is strictly forbidden during the trip. Additionally, please ignore any screaming rocks encountered during the journey.

  • Full Moon Advisory: Passengers with lycanthropy symptoms are advised not to book trips during a full moon. Should you choose to ignore this warning, be aware that you may be permanently hired to replace any equines lost during the journey.

  • Aura Bearers: Passengers with an active aura must remain in the specifically sanctioned areas. We understand the importance of your religion, deity, or patron, but we must consider the comfort of all travelers, including those from other cultures, or those recently returned from the afterlife. Noncompliance will be reported to the nearest guard post.

  • Petrifying Creatures: If your species can petrify others through sight or other means, you must notify staff before boarding. Failure to do so will result in the installation of mirrors around your seat for the duration of the trip.

  • Food Consumption: No food may be consumed during the journey. Multiple rest stops will be provided where you may eat. Other passengers are not considered food, regardless of cultural practices.

  • Safety Notice: Keep all limbs inside the carriage at all times. We are not responsible for any injuries sustained during the journey.

Carrot.name: Carrot
Carrot.description: The steeds' favorite treat after a long trip. Usually, orange in color, though purple, black, red, white, and yellow variants exist depending on the region. Used in most dishes of food. Herbalists sometimes use carrots to create food dyes.

Carved Wooden Toy.name: Carved Wooden Toy
Carved Wooden Toy.description: Carving is one of the favorite activities for traveling merchants or adventurers on long voyages to pass the time. It is easy to learn and practice on the go, and it only requires a small carving knife. The toys or trinkets made from it are either sold to stores or given to close family members.
Carved Wooden Toy.gmNote: Alternative icons exist in the module's folder

Cashmere wool.name: Cashmere wool
Cashmere wool.description: Simply known as cashmere, it is a fiber harvested mainly from specific breeds of goats. Cashmere can be used to create any form of clothing, however, the most common are frocks, which started to be used by middle-class commoners as a representation of status.

Cassiterite.name: Cassiterite
Cassiterite.description: Cassiterite finds itself in a debate between jewelers and blacksmiths, who debate whether it should be classified as a gemstone or an ore akin to tin. Nonetheless, both groups concur that it is highly malleable and easy to work with.

Catfish.name: Catfish
Catfish.description: Catfish, named for its distinctive whisker-like barbels, is a prized catch among anglers. Catfish are best caught using live bait, though herring chunks and chicken livers also yield success. In the hands of a chef, the catfish shines in seafood dishes, whether deep-fried to golden perfection or pan-seared with a medley of herbs and spices, such as lemon, dill, and garlic.

Cauliflower.name: Cauliflower
Cauliflower.description: The most common Cauliflower types come in either green or white, however, more exotic colors such as yellow, orange, and purple also exist. Depending on the region they can be eaten raw, fried, steamed, or even boiled, it is a very common vegetable, however, farmers often say that it is rather hard to maintain, and so they avoid growing it.

Cayenne Pepper.name: Cayenne Pepper
Cayenne Pepper.description: Cayenne pepper is usually ground into a fine powder, which may be a blend of different chili peppers and is known for its intense heat and vibrant flavor. It is used fresh or as a dried powder to spice up seafood, egg dishes, meats, stews, cheese dishes, and hot sauces.

Cedar Log.name: Cedar Log
Cedar Log.description: It is typically harvested from cedar trees that grow in forested areas and is known for its durability and resistance to decay. Cedar logs are often used to create strong and sturdy structures, such as buildings, bridges, and fences, as well as furniture and other wooden objects.

Cedar Plank.name: Cedar Plank
Cedar Plank.description: Because cedar wood is strong and durable, it is an ideal material for creating frames and other structural components of a building. Cedar planks are often used for flooring, siding, roofing, and other applications where strength and stability are important.

Celery.name: Celery
Celery.description: A collection of long, thick, juicy stalks around a central, tender heart. Celery ranges in color from white to green - the darker its color, the stronger its flavor. The stalks are mainly eaten raw in a salad, stir-fried foods, and soups. Occasionally they are also made into juices.

Cendal.name: Cendal
Cendal.description: A form of lightweight silk mainly used to make ceremonial clothing, and church vestments, and help with the decoration of banners.

Centipede.name: Centipede
Centipede.description: Centipedes enter homes seeking food, water, and shelter, same as the common folk, particularly in damp and dark environments. They are attracted to areas with high humidity, such as basements, crawl spaces, and bathrooms, and they hunt other insects for food. While centipedes can bite and inject venom, they are generally not considered dangerous to common folk.

Cerrosafe.name: Cerrosafe
Cerrosafe.description: Cerrosafe is a valuable material in the mold-making industry. Its ability to capture fine details with precision makes it a favorite choice for intricate ceramic and brick molds. Its low melting temperature also means it cannot withstand high heat applications, minimizing its use in processes like metal forging or high-temperature kiln and forge work.

Certificate Holder Cylinder.name: Certificate Holder Cylinder
Certificate Holder Cylinder.description: Simple cylinder designed to hold a large amount of documentation. It is usually carried by tax collectors or couriers to transport a large quantity of papers or documents while traveling. In archives, cylinders are used to store records, helping to occupy less space and be better for organization. These cylinders are often made from durable materials, such as thick leather, metal, or reinforced parchment, to withstand wear and protect important documents during transit.

Chair.name: Chair
Chair.description: Wooden chairs, often found in houses, stores, inns, or taverns, are usually made from planks to allow for easy replacement of parts. This is particularly beneficial in busy venues where chairs may need to be replaced following events like brawls.

Chalcedony.name: Chalcedony
Chalcedony.description: It is speculated that it's sometimes used in Necromancy, mainly a replacement for the human bone, to provide either protection or control over the undead creature. It is also used to carve small cameos or busts in locked pendants, mainly in jewelry

Chalk.name: Chalk
Chalk.description: Chalk is an earthy type of limestone, found mainly in light colors, and is highly sought after, as it can have multiple uses. It is used for writing on slate tables or leaving messages in the wild, to delimit terrain in field sports, in its powder form. It can also be used by tailors and other fabric workers to draw lines and patterns on leather or fabric, to help them cut and sew the material in a precise and accurate way. It is also used in scrying or to create magical symbols and spells on the ground or surfaces, such as walls or doors, to keep out unwanted intruders or to contain a summoned creature.

Chalk Limestone Ashlar.name: Chalk Limestone Ashlar
Chalk Limestone Ashlar.description: Created by the finest masons, tiles were crafted for the exterior stylization of buildings or, in rare cases, as floor tiles. Their light coloring made them a popular choice for the ornamentation of churches, cathedrals, or royal manors constructed from stone. Despite this, their limited durability as tiles led to their replacement with either marble or granite in more recent times.

Chamomile.name: Chamomile
Chamomile.description: Most common folk, when out and about, tend to keep an eye out for Chamomiles, as it grows in the wild. Its use is mainly as a sedative for patients when made into medicinal tea.

Cheese.name: Cheese
Cheese.description: Cheese is a dairy product made from milk that has been curdled and aged. It comes in a variety of flavors and textures and is often used as a condiment or ingredient in cooking in things like pies, pastries and other baked goods.

Cheese Elixir.name: Cheese Elixir
Cheese Elixir.description: This potion is made from a blend of rare and exotic cheeses and a pinch of magic, each with its own unique properties and flavors. When consumed, the Cheese Elixir imbues the drinker with the ability to command and control all forms of cheese, from the softest brie to the hardest parmesan.

Cheese and Greens pie.name: Cheese and Greens pie
Cheese and Greens pie.description: This specific pie is easily made directly in a pan if an oven is not available. An egg, flour, yeast, salted cheese, sugar, and salt are used, and for the greens, anything available can be added, such as nettles, arrach, dill, or parsley. Everything is mixed together into a flatbread and set to cook. Most common folk love this because it's cheap and easy to make.

Cherry.name: Cherry
Cherry.description:
"When the warm seasons hit, and the cherry trees are in bloom, in some cultures, people train their minds and body under these trees. They believe that the spirits of the old guide them and assist them in their training"

Cherries are one of the favorite fruit of young folk everywhere. They can be found in jams, pies, and even homemade juices but are mostly eaten raw.

Chess Pieces.name: Chess Pieces
Chess Pieces.description: Carving chess pieces is a complex task, requiring precise craftsmanship to maintain a consistent style across the set. Each variant of chess, like Courier or Tamerlane, calls for different pieces, adding another layer of complexity and skill to the creation process.

Chick.name: Chick
Chick.description: The chick does not have many uses at this point in its lifespan. However, those who manage the coops tend to separate them for future use, either for meat or for eggs. To earn a little income, the farmer will take some of the chicks to the market for sale.

Chicken.name: Chicken
Chicken.description: Known as poultry, chickens are typically kept by commoners for their reliable supply of eggs to sustain the entire household. The meat is mainly reserved for special occasions like birthdays or holidays, as it does become the centerpiece for a very filling meal.

Chicken Bones.name: Chicken Bones
Chicken Bones.description: Saved after the cutting of a chicken and stored with either magical assistance or brewed concoctions that create freezing temperatures. Farmers typically store these alongside vegetable scraps to make chicken broth or gelatin. After their initial use for stock, remouillage is also made, a second stock that is a bit lighter. The bones can also be ground up for a bone meal as a food supplement for the local livestock.

Chicken Egg.name: Chicken Egg
Chicken Egg.description: Chicken eggs are widely used in many types of dishes, both sweet and savory, including many baked goods. Some of the most common preparation methods include scrambled, fried, poached, hard-boiled, soft-boiled, omelets, and even pickled.

Chicken and Rice.name: Chicken and Rice
Chicken and Rice.description: A staple food in most inns and taverns, as it is easy to prepare, cheap, and it is a hearty meal.

Chili Pepper.name: Chili Pepper
Chili Pepper.description: Harvested usually in most warm climates, it is used mainly as a spice in cuisines to add some "warmth" to the dish.

Chisel.name: Chisel
Chisel.description: This cutting tool is employed by various trades dealing with heavier materials, serving in dressing, shaping, or working solid materials such as wood, stone, or metal. Typically, it is struck with a mallet to ensure precision.

Chitin.name: Chitin
Chitin.description: In underground villages and cities, chitin is a valuable commodity, as it is sturdy and lightweight. This comes from specifically slain insect-like creatures that roam in the darkness. Some farms exist for chitin; however, anything extra brought in by wannabe adventurers is always welcomed, as skilled crafters can turn it into valuable tools, weapons, clothing, or even armor.

Chlorastrolite.name: Chlorastrolite
Chlorastrolite.description: Chlorastrolite is an ornamental gemstone often polished into an oval shape and commonly used in amulets. When in contact with metal, it has the unique ability to turn the metal pale green over extended periods of time. This property has led to the gemstone being referred to as 'Green stone' in some regions.

Chocolate.name: Chocolate
Chocolate.description: Chocolate comes in many shapes, sizes, and tastes. It is a staple sweet primarily made from cocoa beans, sugar, and milk. A major ingredient used in many desserts such as pudding, cakes, and candy. It can be in a solid form like a candy bar or in a liquid form like hot chocolate, to fit various needs and tastes.

Chocolate Biscuits with Fillings.name: Chocolate Biscuits with Fillings
Chocolate Biscuits with Fillings.description: The chocolate biscuits typically feature a crunchy chocolate exterior that encases a variety of jams and peanut fillings. These biscuits are commonly served with teas or juices for the young commoners.

Chocolate Chip Cookie.name: Chocolate Chip Cookie
Chocolate Chip Cookie.description: The chocolate chip cookie is a sweet baked treat that is recognized by its buttery flavor and the inclusion of chocolate chips, which can be dark, milk, or white chocolate depending on personal preference. It's a classic favorite for people of all ages, not just young folk, and is often enjoyed with a cold glass of milk or a warm cup of coffee. Bakers may also experiment with different types of chocolate or cocoa, add nuts or other mix-ins, or even substitute some of the ingredients to create a unique twist on the classic recipe.

Chocolate Navel Orange.name: Chocolate Navel Orange
Chocolate Navel Orange.description: Chocolate Navel Orange, also called simply the chocolate orange. The chocolate orange has a distinctively rich aroma, often reminiscent of vanilla or honey, which enhances most dishes baked or cooked. Its unique aroma goes especially well with dark leafy greens, nuts, and other fruits, making it a favorite in most salads. They can be tossed into salads, used as topping over breakfast dishes such as parfaits and oats or mixed into fruit juices.

Chromite Ingots.name: Chromite Ingots
Chromite Ingots.description: After the ore is smelted into Chromite Ingots, it is usually used to create sturdy tools for extreme climates, whether natural or more magical in nature. Alchemists occasionally use the purified metal smelted from the ore as a catalyst in brewing potions that provide resistance to the elements.

Chromite Ore.name: Chromite Ore
Chromite Ore.description: The Chromite Ore is used primarily in the manufacturing of high-quality steel, sometimes as a replacement for iron but more often combined with it. Depending on the amount used, it can provide metals with beautiful hues of green and red, making the wearers of armor or weaponry manufactured with it quite pleasing to the eye.

Chromite Pigment.name: Chromite Pigment
Chromite Pigment.description: When the Ore is smelted, the fine powder that remains behind is used for glassware as a pigment. Most religious buildings use it on their windows for intricate multi-hued hues and glass murals, representing scenes or deities. It also has some military applications, specifically in camouflage, when made into glass tower shields. If wielded properly, the light reflection off these shields can make the wearer nearly invisible.

Chrysoberyl.name: Chrysoberyl
Chrysoberyl.description: All colored transparent variants of Chrysoberyl are made into gemstones, however, since they are hard to cut and have a limited value to them and they rarely make it into jewelry. Mainly used in magical arts and herbalism as components.

Chrysocolla.name: Chrysocolla
Chrysocolla.description: Chrysocolla, more readily available than turquoise, boasts vivid blue and blue-green colors that have made it popular for carvings and ornamental purposes since ancient times. It is frequently used in silversmithing and goldsmithing as a versatile substitute for turquoise, thanks to its ease of shaping and working with metals.

Chrysoprase.name: Chrysoprase
Chrysoprase.description: Chrysoprase comes in shades ranging from sea glass to deep emerald green, with some specimens showing yellow-green hues like lemon chrysoprase. Often cut in a briolette style, teardrop or oval, it became a popular gemstone for both furniture and jewelry. Additionally, it is used for creating invisible ink when crushed.

Cinnamon.name: Cinnamon
Cinnamon.description: Obtained from the inner bark of several trees, cinnamon is widely used as an aromatic condiment and flavoring additive in many cuisines. It enhances the taste of sweet and savory dishes, bagels, teas, hot chocolate, and traditional foods.

Citrine.name: Citrine
Citrine.description:
"This gem is usually a substitute for Topaz, as they have a very similar shine. As you can imagine someone with an untrained eye could be easily fooled, as it happens time and time again" 

 

This stone bears a close resemblance to an Imperial Topaz or Yellow Sapphire in its hues, however, its value is significantly lower. It is mainly used in jewelry and art ornamentation.

Claw Cup.name: Claw Cup
Claw Cup.description: I’ve drunk from many strange vessels in my years, horns carved from aurochs, clay mugs still warm from the kiln, even a polished turtle shell on the coast, but nothing feels quite like wrapping your hand around a Claw-Cup at Red Harvest. Picture a goblet where the stem is forged iron, darkened and rough as old blood, and shaped into a talon. Its black claws grip a bowl of smoky glass as if it’s holding on for dear life. Some smiths even add scratches and nicks so it looks as though the claw fought for it.

Clay Brick.name: Clay Brick
Clay Brick.description: The clay was shaped into bricks by pushing it into a wooden mold, then heating it in kilns. They can also be glazed with colorful finishes or decorated with intricate patterns, making them a popular choice for decorative building materials.

Cleiophane.name: Cleiophane
Cleiophane.description: Cleiophane is a light-colored gemstone, often seen in hues of yellow, green, or sometimes colorless. Besides its use in jewelry, it can also be utilized in the production of brass, its scarcity and high price mean it is for emergency use only.

Clinozoisite.name: Clinozoisite
Clinozoisite.description: Clinozoisite, known as the Meadstone, is reputed to shield wearers from alcohol poisoning. However, it is also referred to as the 'Blackout stone' due to differing beliefs surrounding its supposed ability to prevent such incidents.

Clover.name: Clover
Clover.description: Clover has long been used as a medicinal herb, by most herbalists, reputed to help everything from cramps to asthma. However, the clover's primary use is mainly used as feed for livestock or added as a fertilizer. In some regions, it is believed that if you find a four-leaf clover, Lady Luck will smile at you. However, most mistake the four-leaf clover with the Wood Sorrel.

Coal.name: Coal
Coal.description:
"It is what I would call the Blacksmith's favorite type of ore. Without good quality coal, they will not be able to do what they do. On a small blacksmithing station you can get away with just some coal and wood, but when it comes to foundries, coal in high quantities is a must."

 

The favorite tool of the metalworker, coal can be found mainly underground, making it one of the most common items uncovered  while mining. Coal can be found close to the surface as well as underground, making dwarfs one of the most prevalent exporters.

Cobalt.name: Cobalt
Cobalt.description: Cobalt is one of the most mistaken ores for a gemstone, due to it’s shape and luster. Some naval fleets prefer cobalt-plated armor for their ships, as it resists the corrosive effects of saltwater far better than any other metal. Some alchemists utilize it for its conductive properties, and it is believed in fringe circles, that containers made from cobalt can store lightning, but these rumors remain unfounded.

Cobnut.name: Cobnut
Cobnut.description: Hazelnuts can be used in multiple dishes, from baked goods, like tarts and cookies, made into a sauce to garnish multiple dishes, to multiple forms of salads.

Coco-Loco.name: Coco-Loco
Coco-Loco.description: Coco-loco is made by opening a fresh coconut and preserving the juice within. After adding a few drops of liqueur, a few drops of rum, pineapple juice, and sugar it is served chilled. This tropical blend is loved during hot seasons, being both sweet and cooling.

Cocoa Beans.name: Cocoa Beans
Cocoa Beans.description: Cocoa beans, found inside cocoa pods, can be crushed to a fine powder or chopped into small pieces for a variety of culinary uses, from salad dressings to cake toppings to making chocolate. The beans are dried, giving them a long shelf life, and making them an excellent commodity for trade between territories.

Coconut.name: Coconut
Coconut.description: The edible fruit of the coconut palm. The pulp or sometimes referred to as the meat of the coconut, is valued for the coconut oil extracted from it. The pulp is also sometimes eaten raw and combined with the daily rations of travelers.

Cod.name: Cod
Cod.description: Codfish can vary in color from red-brown to green-gray on its upper sides, with a silver belly. The best time to catch cod is during their seasonal migrations in the early blossoming seasons or at the end of the harvest seasons when the leaves are brown, offshore. Cod are known to bite on nearly all types of bait, including homemade ones.

Codex Micologica - A Guide to Mushrooms.name: Codex Micologica - A Guide to Mushrooms
Codex Micologica - A Guide to Mushrooms.description: A detailed booklet that showcases the most common mushrooms, categorized by climate, region, and weather. The Codex provides extensive information with clear indications of which mushrooms are safe to eat, safe to brew, which to avoid, and how to store them for extended periods. Carried as a companion both in the wild and in the alchemists' laboratories.

Codex of Hatred & Love.name: Codex of Hatred & Love
Codex of Hatred & Love.description: Small journal titled this way by Valentin Wolfve contains his personal musings on how both love and hatred serve distinct purposes across various fields such as art and research, while he entirely dismisses regret. Several excerpts suggest that through the eyes of a loved one, the most beautiful portraits in history were created, while through hatred, the most in-depth research was pursued solely to discredit opposing causes. As for regret, he simply notes: "One thing you cannot change is what is already done."

Coffee.name: Coffee
Coffee.description: Coffee, a popular hot beverage, is primarily served by taverns in the early mornings, offering commoners a much needed energy boost for the day ahead. The process involves grinding coffee beans into a fine powder, which is then added to a kettle with water. Once the mixture begins to foam and boil, it is served, often accompanied by additional sugar or milk.

Coffee Beans.name: Coffee Beans
Coffee Beans.description: After roasting, the beans can be grounded into a fine powder and brewed into a strong aromatic drink. When consumed it lets you power through long nights, or provides you a boost of energy in the earliest of mornings.

Coffin.name: Coffin
Coffin.description: A coffin is a funerary container used to display or store a corpse before burial or cremation. Depending on cultural traditions and beliefs, it might be reinforced with heavy chains or made of silver, often at great expense, to protect against night creatures.

Cold Feet.name: Cold Feet
Cold Feet.description: Cold Feet has become a summer staple among the rugged commoners. An interesting concoction of mixed wines and foraged spices, it’s famed for inducing a chilling sensation in the limbs. Though its medical benefits are questionable, few question the strongness of the drink, as it does give a buzz and a cool breeze at the same time. Yet, the hangover that comes after is quite memorable.

Common Ling.name: Common Ling
Common Ling.description: Common Ling, or White Ling, is a rare delicacy found only in the pristine waters surrounding tropical islands. Though variations such as Blue Ling and Pink Ling exist, catching one is a difficult task. Its region exclusivity and rarity make it a coveted luxury, served only at the king-run high court opulent feasts and noble banquets.

Common Pandora.name: Common Pandora
Common Pandora.description: Common Pandora, also known as the King of the Breams or Red Pandora, is a highly esteemed food fish. However, fishing boats must venture deep into rough seas and turbulent waters to catch one. Despite the challenging conditions, the fish itself is relatively easy to hook, quickly biting on natural baits such as squid, worms, or shrimp.

Concertina.name: Concertina
Concertina.description: The concertina, the smaller sister to the accordion, is a favorite among seafaring folk due to its compact size, pleasing sound, and easy repairs. Made primarily from giant reed, which grows along the shores of deep rivers, this material is readily available during the ship’s travels, ensuring quick fixes when entertainment is needed.

Contract.name: Contract
Contract.description: A written contract between two parties that outlines the specifics for a job, trade, or other arrangement. It is signed by both parties and stamped with a seal by a third party as a witness. The contract can include as many details as required for the request at hand. It is typically provided in three copies, one for each party involved.

Copper Ingot.name: Copper Ingot
Copper Ingot.description: Copper Ingot, once purified in the smelter, are used in the production of household utensils, weapons, armor, agricultural tools, and furniture ornamentation. They are often used by rookie blacksmiths as a training metal since their lower melting point reduces fuel consumption compared to many sturdy metals.

Copper Ore.name: Copper Ore
Copper Ore.description: Copper ore is commonly found in multiple veins alongside a variety of other metals. It is easily identified by its reddish-brown color. It serves as the foundation for multiple alloys, such as brass or bronze, and is also an important metal in coin minting in all regions. Arcane casters experiment with copper metal rods in enchanted devices, believing it enhances the flow of arcane energy.

Copper Ring.name: Copper Ring
Copper Ring.description: This simple metal ring is made out of copper. It's a great metal for making jewelry due to its ease of molding, durability, and unique reddish-brown color. Commoners attuned to spiritual practices often wear it with a strong belief, feeling it actively channels positive energy and attracts good fortune into their lives.

Copper Slag.name: Copper Slag
Copper Slag.description: When copper is extracted through smelting, impurities rise to the surface as copper slag. This material has become a permanent construction resource, used for road pavements and as a replacement for sand in mortar for building materials.

Coral.name: Coral
Coral.description: Powdered Coral was a very desirable ingredient in creating potions of healing because it guaranteed greater minimum effectiveness for those healing droughts. Currently used only to create rare red dye.

Cordovan Cut.name: Cordovan Cut
Cordovan Cut.description: The finest leatherworker cut, named after a city from the mountainside, which had several crafters that were able to cure the leather in such a way that it was so pristine that it became renowned quite quickly. While the pelt does come from cowhide, the curing, drying, and processing result made it famous among the realms.

Corn.name: Corn
Corn.description: Corn is one of the most farmed grains, as it can be turned into oil and flour. Corn itself is a staple food throughout the realms for all consumers and their livestock. The plant in itself is called Maize and it is usually planted as the warmer seasons begin because it is not resistant to the cold.

Cornet.name: Cornet
Cornet.description: The cornet sometimes called the circular trumpet or natural cornet, is primarily crafted from brass by master blacksmiths in specialized forges. Its unique valve system ensures a clear and resonant sound, making precision in its manufacturing essential for skilled smiths.

Corvus Corax.name: Corvus Corax
Corvus Corax.description: The Corvus Corax is more commonly referred to as a raven skull. It is mainly used by the most superstitious folk as a guiding talisman or threaded upon a chain or lace and hung as a charm. For others is a symbol of wisdom, intelligence, and insight. It can also represent mortality and is a symbol of transformation, depending on the region, tradition, and folklore.

Cotton.name: Cotton
Cotton.description: Cotton farming is relatively straightforward as most city-states have dedicated regions of farmland specifically for it, as it is one of the most widely used materials in clothing and indoor decoration.

Covered Fruit Tart.name: Covered Fruit Tart
Covered Fruit Tart.description: The recipe for this tart is quite simple and is a favorite in most households and bakeries alike. It includes flour, milk, sweeteners such as sugar or honey, and a variety of fruits. The most common fruits used for the pies are apples, pears, cherries, grapes, and many more, and often a mixture of them are used to create unique flavor combinations. These tarts are a beloved treat among adventurers and travelers alike. They evoke feelings of nostalgia and a longing for home, and provide a satisfying energy boost to help them on their future adventures.

Cow.name: Cow
Cow.description: Cows are considered one of the most farmed animals, they are precious to farmhands as none of their materials go to waste. From staple products like meat or dairy to hides for leather, glue extracted from the hide and bones, to the crafting of silverware, pins, fishhooks, flutes, or bone needles, every aspect of a cow's harvesting is utilized to its fullest.
