Cowhide.name: Cowhide
Cowhide.description: Material harvested through husbandry and provided to the leatherworkers for further processing, to make sure nothing is wasted from the butchering of the bovine. The hides are bought in large batches, as this is the most common type of hide to make the leather for military equipment.

Crab.name: Crab
Crab.description: Crabs are abundant across many climates and fairly simple to catch, yet their demand keeps their price high. Fishermen use sturdy steel-wire traps, often baited with chicken or small fish, to lure them in. Prized in culinary circles, crabs become an irresistible delicacy when cooked with butter, garlic, and aromatic spices.

Cranesbill.name: Cranesbill
Cranesbill.description: Cranesbill is a garden plant, that has multiple medicinal uses. Most commoners keep them around their houses to make tea. Cranesbill is an herb that can be used as a mouth rinse to soothe the pain of canker sores, and also made as a hot brew, to soothe stringent stomach aches.

Creamatory.name: Creamatory
Creamatory.description: There’s a saying on the market, if the cream leaves a perfect spiral after your first sip, your year will end in fortune. If it curdles instead, best not travel far from home, as bad luck awaits. A long time ago, I had ignored that superstition, laughed it off, even mocked it, and ended up breaking an cart axle in the dark swamps, and got stranded for a few days 'till, it got fixed. Since then, I always watch the cream's shape. Call me foolish, but when you’ve seen cream clump into a shapes only on that specific evening, you learn to give the drink its respect.

Crimson Lady.name: Crimson Lady
Crimson Lady.description: Crimson Lady is a cocktail drink, made from vodka, lemon, and tomato juice, spicy ground red pepper for a bit of spice. It is usually prepared in large batches and kept cold. It can be topped with pickled vegetables, garlic, horseradish, celery, olives, and black pepper. Usually made in large batches for quick servings.

Crimson Noble Slab.name: Crimson Noble Slab
Crimson Noble Slab.description: These specific slabs are made of 100% pure gold, weighing around 2.2 lbs, and for the longest time, they were simply known as Noble Gold Slabs. As people started using the slabs more frequently for nefarious deeds, they changed the name from Noble Gold Slabs to Crimson Noble Slabs. Nobility tends to use these for payment, as they are not marked with their family seals, to help sort out any forms of rivalry, from coups, and subversions to assassinations. These slabs are widely accepted by the majority merchants, who understand that they represent a completed transaction. Refusing them could potentially put them and their loved ones in danger.

Crow Feathers.name: Crow Feathers
Crow Feathers.description: The crow is a clever creature, when making it, most say it's a watcher and a guide, a creature that knows the secrets of both the field and the midden. Binding two of its feathers is said to capture a small sliver of that cunning, and for the red string tied to its base? That acts as a focus. It binds the magic, so to speak, keeps it from wandering off. This specific suppersticion is divided as for every soul who sees it as a lucky charm, there’s another who’ll spit on the ground and call it a fool’s gamble.

Crucible Steel.name: Crucible Steel
Crucible Steel.description: When blacksmiths get access to ancient magic, the forge becomes a sacred place. Here the finest weapons and armor are crafted. The most prized of these metals is crucible steel, which is known for its strength and durability. In times long gone it was said that crucible steel was forged in the fiery depths of the earth, tempered by the heat of a thousand suns. It was so strong that it could hold its edge even against the sharpest of blades. The finest blacksmiths would spend hours, if not days, working the crucible steel, carefully shaping it into the desired form. The result was a weapon or piece of armor that was virtually indestructible.

Cucumber.name: Cucumber
Cucumber.description: Cucumbers are usually either eaten raw, in salads or sometimes cooked, in very specific dishes. They can also be preserved over winter in a concoction of salt, wild dill and water, or vinegar.

Cumin.name: Cumin
Cumin.description: Cumin seed is used as a spice for its distinctive flavor and aroma. It can be found in some cheeses, such as Leyden cheese, and can be added while making bread. This spice is a staple in many realm cuisines, enhancing dishes with its warm, earthy taste.

Cured Hide.name: Cured Hide
Cured Hide.description: An regular cured hide that is sold in bulk by the leatherworkers, which is usually used in the other trades. Blacksmiths usually use them for the weapon hilts, while tailors use them for intricate dresses or beautiful bags, and the commoners use them to make leather strips for various uses.

Currants.name: Currants
Currants.description: Red, white, and pink currants can be eaten out of hand but are commonly turned into jams, jellies, and desserts. Most blackcurrants are grown for their acidic juice but are also made into delicious preserves and desserts.

Cutting Board.name: Cutting Board
Cutting Board.description: Cutting boards are made from leftover lumber, which is glued and shaped into practical kitchen tools. As customers quite rarely purchase new boards, carpenters add a personal touch by offering custom logos or names burned into the surface, making each piece unique.

Cymophane.name: Cymophane
Cymophane.description: Cymophane, when fashioned into beads, earns the name "Cat's Eye" from its ability to reflect light in a manner that mimics the appearance of a feline's eye.

Cypher - Text.name: Cypher - Text
Cypher - Text.description: This cylinder often serves as a secure container, designed to protect valuable or sensitive items, ensuring that only those with the correct knowledge can open it. They are usually made with written details on a cylinder, the instructions describe the steps required to open and access the item inside. Breaking the cipher open carries a high risk of triggering a fail-safe that could destroy the item within.

D'Ochre Pie.name: D'Ochre Pie
D'Ochre Pie.description: This unusual pie, known for its acidic sweetness, is a specialty that only a handful of bakeries know how to make. Its unique texture is said to come from a secret ingredient obtained from hunts, although the specifics of this ingredient remain uncertain. While the bakers are famously tight-lipped about their recipe, the pie is a must-try for adventurous eaters. Its tartness can be overpowering for some, but those who enjoy it savor the complex flavors and satisfying chewiness, and some say that it taste like very sweet oranges. Due to its potent acidity, bakers typically only sell one piece per customer and while there are rumors that the pie is linked to a rare disease, however, the bakers are quickly to deny any links.

Daer-Kron.name: Daer-Kron
Daer-Kron.description: To plant the Dark-Kron seed, a miner picks a small round hole, places the seed inside, and uses either ground bones mixed with wax as a nutrient source, or a combination of wood, charcoal, and glue to plug the hole. After three days, a soft light begins to emanate from the wall where the Daer-Kron seed was planted. Slowly, a mushroom unfurls, casting an eerie but comforting glow throughout the chamber, called Neon-Ront. For those navigating the underground depths, these fungi are not just lights but beacons, guiding them safely through dark tunnels.

Daliumite.name: Daliumite
Daliumite.description: It is known for its shimmering, golden appearance, often confused with gold, and is highly prized by blacksmiths. They usually wait months, if not years, for only small amounts of the ore, however, when they manage to obtain it, they will always turn a profit. When worked into bars, its surface is covered in intricate, swirling patterns that seem to change and shift as the ingot is moved. When held in the hand, daliumite feels warm to the touch and seems to have a faint vibration.

Danburite.name: Danburite
Danburite.description: Danburite is a transparent to translucent gem that ranges from colorless to light yellow, or pale pink to light brown in color. Depending on the culture or region it is acquired from, it is believed to have healing properties; however, herbalists nor any of the religious folk can confirm it.

Dandelion.name: Dandelion
Dandelion.description: Dandelion leaves add flavor to salads, sandwiches, and teas. The roots are used in some coffee substitutes, and the flowers are used to make wines. Dandelions are definitely safe to eat both raw and cooked, and you can eat almost all parts of the dandelion. They can also be used for medicinal purposes, as they are one of the best greens that can be used in anti-inflammation tinctures.

Dark Red Diamond.name: Dark Red Diamond
Dark Red Diamond.description: The gem is cut in a round shape, and when it refracts light it looks as if fire is embedded in it.  In the right light, these polished gems resemble droplets of blood. They usually come in dark red to brownish-red colors. The are also know as the most expensive variant of a diamond. It is speculated that when a spell is cast with its help, part of the caster's soul gets consumed along with the diamond.

Dark River Gold.name: Dark River Gold
Dark River Gold.description: These coins, of unknown origin, are always discovered by fishermen, but when they appear, they are seen as a bad omen. After they are found in the rivers or seas, trade and communication with nearby cities slows down or stops, and rumors of monster invasions, tsunamis, and fires tend to emerge from the region. The source of these rumors is not yet verified. However, owners of the coins tend to quickly trade them for almost no profit, despite their rarity, possibly due to the perceived negative association.

Dark Rose.name: Dark Rose
Dark Rose.description: You won't find this harvested and cared for in any proper garden, and thank the stars for that. I had only ever seen it in ashy soil of old forgotten battlefields or in the silent, dark and thick forests where the very air feels damp, old and watchful. Its stems and leaves are the deep purple of a day old bruise, veined with a crimson so dark it’s nearly black, while the flower itself, does resemble blood in color. It has no scent, instead, it carries a metallic smell, like dread on the wind, and the melancholy decay of the forgotten.

Dark-Bat Remains.name: Dark-Bat Remains
Dark-Bat Remains.description: When the creatures of the night transform into their more animalistic parts, hunters chasing them only have one alternative to resolve their hunts. Decapitation. Doing so burns the flesh and skin off the creature leaving behind only its skull. The skull is usually kept as a trophy, and quite cherished, as surviving one of these creatures is a rare feat.

Darkness Eye.name: Darkness Eye
Darkness Eye.description: The first time I saw a Darkness Eye, it was in the cracked palm of a street vendor in Marrowgate, and I swear the thing looked like it was swallowing the light whole. A gem, indeed, but not one that glitters or winks at you, with it's jumping colors. Its surface is dull and black as pitch, yet somehow deeper than any pit. Stare too long, and your stomach tightens as though you’re falling into it. Some say it’s not stone at all, but a fragment of night itself created into a round shape.

Darmouth Bass.name: Darmouth Bass
Darmouth Bass.description: Dartmouth Bass prefer clear, shallow waters in ponds and lakes, often found near aquatic vegetation, submerged timber, or rocky outcroppings. Scholars have dedicated entire books to the art of Dartmouth Bass fishing. In more established territories, local fisheries require a dedicated fishing license to catch this prized fish. Without one, any captured Dartmouth Bass must be released, or the fisher might even face jail time, on top of a hefty fine.

Date Fruit.name: Date Fruit
Date Fruit.description: They grow on date palm trees, instead of bananas or coconuts, imagine hundreds of dates. They can be used in multiple dishes from cookies to salted date caramel.

Datolite.name: Datolite
Datolite.description: Historical records indicate that Datolite was once utilized as a form of currency. However, its vulnerability to wear and tear prompted its replacement with more durable metal coins, which became universally recognized. While still valued, the gemstone's historical significance has gradually faded.

Death Cap.name: Death Cap
Death Cap.description: The most favored mushroom by the most unfavorable people. The consumption of the Death Cap is more often than not fatal. In most forests close to civilization, signs are put up to warn people against eating random mushrooms due to the Death Caps growing almost anywhere.

Deep Blue Spinel.name: Deep Blue Spinel
Deep Blue Spinel.description: A superb crystal of deep blue-violet colors, usually worn in jewelry.

Deep Green Spinel.name: Deep Green Spinel
Deep Green Spinel.description: Beloved by the forest folk, this type of spinel is used to adorn armor and weaponry, also used in pendants, rings, or bracelets.

Demontoid.name: Demontoid
Demontoid.description: Demantoid, one of the scarcest garnet types, exhibits a vivid color comparable to emerald and sparkle that exceeds even diamonds. Highly sought after by both gem connoisseurs and jewelry aficionados, demantoids are typically sold at a premium way above their regional price.

Detonator.name: Detonator
Detonator.description: A tool highly favored by miners, its combination with gunpowder explosive facilitates the rapid creation of holes or tunnels to reach the more interesting metals beneath the ground. Nevertheless, due to the occasional instability of the explosions and the rare risk of shrapnel damaging mine supports, drills tend to be the preferred choice.

Diamond Arcana.name: Diamond Arcana
Diamond Arcana.description: Created by the most skilled arcane masters and gem cutters. Formed from a single flawless diamond, the entire band is carved directly from the stone itself, shaped through forgotten arcane techniques rather than conventional tools. Each ring becomes part of a greater arcane economy, moving between powerful hands for very expensive spells.

Diasper.name: Diasper
Diasper.description: A cloth created mostly with linen, sometimes cotton, or a combination of both. Mainly used as a table cloth, however, due to the absorbent nature of the fabric, it is also used in covering newborns, and in that case it is referred to as a diaper.

Dictionary.name: Dictionary
Dictionary.description: This book contains all the words in a language along with their specific definitions. It is especially helpful for those attempting to learn the language, uncover archaic terms or regionalisms, and to also resolve complex puzzles.

Didntonite.name: Didntonite
Didntonite.description: Didntonite is an ornamental stone prized for its fibrous texture, combining both toughness and softness. While predominantly grayish-pink, it is occasionally found with striking rings of blue, green, white, and brown, adding to its aesthetic appeal.

Diopside.name: Diopside
Diopside.description: This stone is available in white, green, or yellow hues, often mixed together. It is dubbed "The Fortune Stone" for those who discover it, recognized as the "Stone of Service" awarded for outstanding military achievements, and revered as the "Stone of Mother Earth" among Druidic circles, believed to bestow blessings upon the land.

Dioptase.name: Dioptase
Dioptase.description: Dioptase is greatly favored by gem collectors and is sometimes fashioned into small gems for jewelry. Another use for the gemstone is that it can also be pulverized and used as a pigment for painting.

Distilation Gear.name: Distilation Gear
Distilation Gear.description: Many alchemists and taverns keep one because it is used to improve the quality of potions and drinks. Creating the finest potions or strongest beverages require its use, but since the process takes a great deal of time, the final product often becomes very expensive.

Djembe.name: Djembe
Djembe.description: The djembe, sometimes referred to as simply the jembe, is a rope-tuned drum played with bare hands. Its name, in some areas, translates to 'everyone gathers together in peace', embodying unity and community spirit. The drum’s shell is carved from hardwood, while its head is traditionally made from untreated goat rawhide, reflecting its deep cultural roots.

Dobsonfly.name: Dobsonfly
Dobsonfly.description: Dobsonfly is a very large insect, insect that is born from a larva known as the hellgrammite. It feeds on aquatic insects, nectar, sugar water, worms, and even small fish. While the huge size of it, can be intimidating. Dobsonfly’s brief lifespan of about a week and its nocturnal habits mean that many commoners may go their whole lives without encountering one.

Draconic Staters.name: Draconic Staters
Draconic Staters.description: These coins, historically known as the first coins ever used, have undergone little modification throughout time. They are typically crafted by the minions of dragons, and always feature a carving of a dragon's wing or head. The dragons' hoards often contain varying qualities of precious metals, resulting in the coins being minted with a lower gold price compared to others on the market. Depending on the region, they may also be referred to as "wings" based on their symbol.

Dragon Bones.name: Dragon Bones
Dragon Bones.description: The most commonly collected bones come from the huge dragons and due to it, the transportation of them is usually a logistic nightmare. However, due to their size and light weight, some of the small more tribal villages can be used in the construction of huts, fences, or even walls.

Dragon Eyes.name: Dragon Eyes
Dragon Eyes.description: Dragon's Eyes are simple, yet gorgeous pieces of jewelry. These earrings are typically crafted as a pair that accompany a necklace and are bestowed exclusively upon royalty, traditionally during coronation ceremonies. The intricate craftsmanship required for these earrings is entrusted only to the most renowned gem cutters and jewelers. In the glint of the jewels, when light strikes them just so, some speculate that the watchful eye of an actual dragon might be glimpsed.

Dragon Fruit.name: Dragon Fruit
Dragon Fruit.description: Depending on the region, sometimes also called a Pitaya. The fruit has bright red skin and green scales that slightly resemble a dragon, hence the name.

Dragon Heart.name: Dragon Heart
Dragon Heart.description: Dragon Heart is a pendant fit for an emperor, a masterpiece typically accompanied by its counterpart, the Dragon's Eyes earrings. The jewelry pieces are crafted from the same rare gemstone sharing the Dragon Heart name. Due to the gem's extreme rarity, only the most famous gem cutters and jewelers are permitted to cut and set these stones. The work made transforms raw rarity into symbols of godlike power.

Dragon Scale.name: Dragon Scale
Dragon Scale.description: An actual dragon scale, attached to a piece of string, serves more as a symbolic trophy indicating that the owner is a dragon slayer. However, due to the rarity of dragon scales in the realms, not attached to the said dragons, collectors, and in some cases, more nefarious parties, may offer a significant premium to acquire it, depending on the color of the scale.

Dragon Scales.name: Dragon Scales
Dragon Scales.description: The scales do not have many uses, yet, stories travel the lands, that, you can, in a time of need, use the scales as an improvised defense tool, as they are quite sturdy and have a similar shape to a shield, and they can resist the element from which dragon the scale came from.

Dragon Talons.name: Dragon Talons
Dragon Talons.description: The sharpness of the dragon's talons can cut through the most finely crafted steel. Considering their size, they are sometimes repurposed into handcrafted weapons, depending on the size, can make either the sturdy-sharp shortswords or the lightest longswords.

Dragon Touch.name: Dragon Touch
Dragon Touch.description: Dragon Touch ring is a scam ring piece, deliberately marketed as the missing third component to complete the prestigious set featuring 'Dragon's Eyes' earrings and the 'Dragon Heart' pendant. Primarily manufactured from Iron Pyrite and a cheap Agate, it does posses some value. However, the moment the piece of jewelry proves not to be what it was sold as, the silver-tongued scammer is nowhere to be seen.

Dragon's Skull.name: Dragon's Skull
Dragon's Skull.description: Collectors love these types of skulls mainly due to their rarity. They go above and beyond just to get their hands on the skulls from adventurers, usually at a very fair price. However, based on the age and size of the dragon, these can vary wildly in price; sometimes, the price of one can exceed that of the most polished magical gemstones in existence. When it comes to their uses, they are mainly ornamental in nature, usually displayed in local museums.

Dragon’s Heart.name: Dragon’s Heart
Dragon’s Heart.description: According to legends, the Dragon's Heart is a rare gemstone that is said to be formed from the molten core of a dragon. It is believed to contain the essence of the dragon's power and strength. However, this belief is unverified, as the gem is typically discovered in the aftermath of a dragon's death or when a dragon vacates its lair. The discovery of the Dragon's Heart is a recent one, made by adventurers and treasure hunters who ventured into dragon's lairs in search of treasure and glory. The gem can only be found in caves, caverns, or mines that have been used as a dragon's lair. It is said that after a period of time, the gem will appear in the center of the lair, as if the earth itself has spit it out. Due to the limited number of these gems discovered, the Dragon's Heart is considered one of the most valuable and expensive gems available for trade.

Drayweight Leather.name: Drayweight Leather
Drayweight Leather.description: This cut of leather is mostly a scam, and when merchants sell it, they use the name of Drayweight, as it sounds a bit more fantastical, however, the leather itself is rather common, but quite heavy. The peddlers tend to joke around as it is worth its weight in silver, but someone with some familiarity with quality gear will quickly identify that this cut isn't anything special.

Dreamfreezer's Draft.name: Dreamfreezer's Draft
Dreamfreezer's Draft.description: This potion is normally used by clerics, herbalists, or medics of any form, for under-the-skin extraction of critters, or helping with life-threatening surgeries. The potion causes the user to go into a comatose-like state, and when under it, it is believed that forgotten and current deities come to chitchat, however, this has never been proven to any degree of accuracy. The downside of the potion is that different users have different resistance to it, and once the surgery starts, the lead assigned medic for that situation needs to move quickly, as there is no constant clear time-frame. It can be minutes or even hours depending on who consumed the potion. Forrest folk are fully immune to this potion.

Dried Meat.name: Dried Meat
Dried Meat.description: The process of drying meat is long and extensive. In some particular cases, for the highest quality of dried meat, it can take over a year. It is highly sought after due to its extended shelf life, and depending on the meat used, it is, quite frankly, delicious.

Drill.name: Drill
Drill.description: This handheld mechanical drill operates through gears and oil, spinning in a steady circular motion to dig deeper into a single point. It requires skilled miners familiar with tinkering, as the rocky terrain often wears down the drill head, demanding frequent replacement.

Drinking Horn.name: Drinking Horn
Drinking Horn.description: A drinking horn is usually made from either animal horns or large tusks. Variants are known to be made from glass, wood, ceramics, or even metal by skilled silversmiths. Depending on the region, these horns can have ceremonial purposes, either acknowledging two newly-weds marriage, or a friend's passing.

Duck.name: Duck
Duck.description: Primarily raised for their meat, ducks also yield eggs of higher value as they are quite nutritious. Commoners often keep them around the house for an extended period compared to regular hens, as ducks don't need elaborate housing, resistant to diseases, and efficiently remove small pests like snails or slugs.

Dumplings.name: Dumplings
Dumplings.description: Dumplings are commonly made by combining flour or meal with egg and then simmering the mixture in water until it reaches a light, cakey texture. To add flavor, some recipes, add various ingredients such as herbs, onions, grated cheese, or chopped meat mixed with the dough before cooking.

Dung Beetle.name: Dung Beetle
Dung Beetle.description: Dung Beetle their appearance does show that a pasture is quite healthy, as they are perfect in breaking down and burying animal waste, improving the soil. While, a bit controvesial, in some regions, they are used in cooking. After capturing they are cleaned, roasted, and dehydrated, sometimes with added seasonings. Some recipes involve trimming the wings and legs of the beetles, then stir-frying them with oil, basil, chiles, and lemongrass until crispy.

Dungeon Plans.name: Dungeon Plans
Dungeon Plans.description: A dungeon plan schematic contains the full layout of a specific dungeon, either already built or planned to be constructed beneath a castle, fort, or large dwelling, such as a manor. Dungeons are typically used to hold prisoners until a trial. While the dungeon itself is not intended for long-term confinement, it is not unheard of for prisoners to remain there for extended periods. The schematic often includes areas specifically designed for interrogation, storage of evidence, or other purposes tied to the ruling authority’s needs.

Duralumin.name: Duralumin
Duralumin.description: Duralumin, a durable and lightweight aluminum alloy, is employed in the most advanced territories for flight-related applications. Only a select few master blacksmiths can create and mold this alloy. It is also used to make armor for creatures that can fly.

Durian.name: Durian
Durian.description: The durian fruit has a tough, round, green and spiky exterior, with a soft edible core. Its harvesting has to be done rather quickly in most tropical regions, once temperatures drop, as the fruit abruptly stops growing. Even though it is considered one of the most amazing fruits, its odor keeps most common folk at bay. Its smell often being compared to the spray of a skunk or raw sewage.

Dusk Warning.name: Dusk Warning
Dusk Warning.description: Dusk Warning is a fine whiskey that exudes class, with a smooth yet pronounced profile highlighted by the rich smokiness of peat moss. Each sip reveals layers of character, earthy, spicy, and just a touch sweet. It's a favorite in refined taverns, often served with glazed fruits or creamy soups.

Eggplants.name: Eggplants
Eggplants.description: Most commonly purple, the spongy, absorbent fruit is used in several cuisines, depending on the region, and can also be found under the name of aubergine or brinjal. Typically used as a vegetable in cooking eggplant salad which contains sunflower oil, salt, and eggplants roasted over open fire.

Eggs and Sausage.name: Eggs and Sausage
Eggs and Sausage.description: A simple yet hearty breakfast for all commoners, this dish gets the day going. It can be served with a side of beans, or for those who prefer a lighter meal, with their morning coffee.

Eggs, Rice, and Green Beans.name: Eggs, Rice, and Green Beans
Eggs, Rice, and Green Beans.description: A very hearty meal, the eggs complement the rice well, and the rice pairs wonderfully with the beans. This dish comes highly recommended by most tavern keepers.

Electrum.name: Electrum
Electrum.description: Sometimes referred to as Green Gold if manufactured, or White Gold, if it is a naturally occurring alloy. Primarily composed of Gold and Silver. In most cities, the balance between gold and silver is roughly 50-50 for the Electrum coin or bars manufacturing, however, in the more remote areas a higher percentage of silver is used. Due to this, most regions have stopped using Electrum coins altogether, as they match the big cities' manufacturing style.

Elemental Debt.name: Elemental Debt
Elemental Debt.description: This magical coin has an undefined value, which depends on the material used to create it. It is primarily used as a material that is about to be consumed for spells that have specific prerequisites. Magical alloys with pearls, diamonds, bones, and silver are commonly used to make these coins. Each coin bears the magical sygil representing the type of spell it can be used for, and this symbol also determines its value. These coins are typically found in major cities with a magical college that has the ability to craft them.

Embalming Fluid.name: Embalming Fluid
Embalming Fluid.description: This fluid is specifically made to preserve the dead for later use either for dissections or burial practices, or even necromancy. The fluid in itself is considered poison for regular people that might be considering consuming it. The embalmed corpse has a lower decaying rate than their non-embalmed counterparts.

Emerald.name: Emerald
Emerald.description: Translucent Emeralds are cut and polished in gem cuts for jewelry. Mainly provided as gifts for royalty or nobility. In the past it was associated with health, fertility, and growth and used to adorn magical items that improved the healing arts.

Epidote.name: Epidote
Epidote.description: The Epidote, an ornamental stone abundant in various mines, is prized for its dual utility. It is notably used as an ingredient in potions designed to ward off the unliving and as ink for inscribing scrolls.

Equipment Order.name: Equipment Order
Equipment Order.description: An official edict calling for a large quantity of gear, including both armor and weapons, is typically issued as a preparation for war or to support an ongoing conflict. In return, blacksmiths submit a material order, estimating the necessary amounts of supplies to fulfill the request.

Essonite.name: Essonite
Essonite.description: Essonite, often known as the "Cinnamon Stone", earned this nickname because, like the spice, it was once more valuable than a bar of gold. However, its purchasing power has diminished compared to its esteemed position in the past.

Euclase.name: Euclase
Euclase.description: Euclase was easily cut into faceted gems and came in various colors ranging from colorless to pale yellow, vivid yellow, pale green, and blue. The blue hues commanded the highest price. There's speculation that this specific gem is not reacting well to any form of arcane arts, as when it interacts with them, it explodes into a small ball of glass and shrapnel.

Evernight.name: Evernight
Evernight.description: Evernight is considered a collector's brew, due in part to its mysterious behavior. When drunk, another bottle is said to appear on a random shelf, anywhere in the realms, among other drinks. Over the ages, alchemists, herbalists, brewers, and brewers have all tried to recreate it, but with no success. Its unique properties and unknown ingredients have rendered it truly priceless. One persistent rumor claims that when combined with Morning Breeze and Pure Day, it grants immortality. However, due to its vanishing nature, no one has ever managed to unite the three into a mixture.

Exoskeleton.name: Exoskeleton
Exoskeleton.description: When the huge arachnids shed they do leave behind their exoskeletons. The pieces of the spider's shell are in high demand, as they are flexible and can be easily molded in multiple shapes. Rumors say that someone wearing armor made of exoskeleton pieces has his internal strength increased ten-fold.

Expensive Fish & Where to Get Them.name: Expensive Fish & Where to Get Them
Expensive Fish & Where to Get Them.description: The book quickly delves into details about various fishing areas; however, much of the information appears incomplete or misleading. It is commonly sold in taverns by self-proclaimed famous fishermen, often targeting unskilled commoners as part of a get-rich-quick scheme. The basic premise encourages readers to simply head to the nearest body of water, catch whatever they can, and sell it for profit. Throughout the book, a recurring tagline is used as an incentive: "One catch can change your life. Here's how!"

Exploding Stick.name: Exploding Stick
Exploding Stick.description: Exploding sticks are usually named that way for drilling purposes, to create small cracks in heavy solid rock or ore so that a pickaxe or a drill can follow up. There is usually a specialized machinist who makes them using the finest gunpowder and also sets them up. They will not produce a big bang, but they will get the job done in clearing rocks.

Faction Earrings.name: Faction Earrings
Faction Earrings.description: As a symbolic gesture, when joining very specific and well-renowned factions, a ring or a pair of earrings is provided as a welcome gift, along with other paraphernalia such as pens or notebooks bearing the same symbol. This helps quickly identify members and also gives the initial illusion of belonging.

Faded Map.name: Faded Map
Faded Map.description: Faded map which points to an unknown location, the text is too indecipherable to distinguish any cities, regions, or forest names. A highly skilled cartographer might provide some insight on the specifics of the map itself, such as when it was made based on the paper or ink used.

Fae Bon.name: Fae Bon
Fae Bon.description:
"This was first shown to me by a tiny creature. It had difficulty speaking, and when he presented me with these specific bones, I think he meant to say 'bones,' but I am unsure now."

Fae Bons come from creatures that live within underground stone cave systems. They can double as candles, emitting some light, albeit limited. They can glow in multiple hues, including red, blue, cyan, green, purple, or even pink. Despite having a name associated with fantastical creatures, they do not come from any Fae-like creatures but from underground monstrosities.

Fan.name: Fan
Fan.description: Primarily made out of paper, or rarely from cloth, and reinforced with either light metals, such as tin, or light woods, like redwood. The fans feature intricate designs, with many crafted to reflect regional symbols or family crests. Some fans, adorned with vibrant colors or delicate embroidery, are considered status symbols and are cherished as heirlooms. On a blistering summer day, villagers unfold their fans with a flick of the wrist, a synchronized dance of fabric and wood, creating a gentle breeze that brings momentary relief from the sun's relentless heat.

Fangs Necklace.name: Fangs Necklace
Fangs Necklace.description: Ah, the Fangs Necklace. Every year, just before the Red Harvest fires are lit, jewelers from Dockhaven to the hill markets of Bristlethorn start cutting these out by the dozen. It’s a mostly dramatic piece, for decoration. Quite sharp, toothlike pendants dangling from a wire or chain, usually fashioned from red glass or smoky quartz. Some gemmasters will cut actual garnets into points, but most of what you’ll see glittering in the market stalls is mostly clever work with colored glass. When worn in torchlight, the pieces catch a red glimmer that looks unsettlingly like fresh blood, aimed to resemble the night fangs.

Fat Candle.name: Fat Candle
Fat Candle.description: Fat candles are crafted from rendered animal fat, such as whale blubber or tallow from sheep and cows. Although beeswax candles last longer, these candles burn more brightly and cost significantly less. The downside is that they release an unpleasant foul odor while burning.

Favor Coin.name: Favor Coin
Favor Coin.description: "Each favor has a price” stands etched on the side of the golden coin in a forgotten language. Usually traded and manufactured by nefarious groups for an underground economy. If a service is required, a coin must be paid. The services offered can range from a piece of vestment, advanced weaponry, to castle plans, to the swift disposal of bodies. All favors, all have a price.

Ferrochrome Aquarum.name: Ferrochrome Aquarum
Ferrochrome Aquarum.description: A very rare alloy, forgotten by time, with unknown schematics and properties. Its strength is as durable as iron when molded into shape, yet when the metal is moved, small ripples similar to rain splatter waves appear on it. Alchemists and casters who tried to identify it have been baffled, leading to dangerous consequences. Yet it is not magical in nature. A common, silent agreement among alchemists is that when adventurers ask for identification, they simply describe it as a hardened liquid metal.

Fiddle.name: Fiddle
Fiddle.description: The fiddle, more commonly known as the violin, is often used for music that focuses on dancing. The distinction between the two lies in how the music is played. The fiddle is characterized by fast rhythms and quick note changes, while the violin typically produces a more mellow sound with longer, sustained notes. The instrument’s name depends on the style in which it is played.

Fig.name: Fig
Fig.description: Figs can be eaten fresh, dried or processed into jam for rolls, biscuits, and other types of desserts. Since they are somewhat hard to preserve figs are gathered when they fall and placed on trays for drying, added depending on the region they can be added to rations when traveling.

Fight Beneath the Surface Ch. 1.name: Fight Beneath the Surface Ch. 1
Fight Beneath the Surface Ch. 1.description:
"North Noria was once the epicenter of the region plagued by Kah'Yul’s influence.

In response, Cleric Anilisia, chief of the Red Obsidian, sought to plant a Young Virathryn sapling, a sacred tree said to bridge the mortal world to Kah'Yul's realm. She planted it within the overground chambers, believing that its growth toward the sky would forge the connection she needed.

However, her not-so-friendly sisters, who opposed her plan, had already made their move, poisoning the soil in secret.

Days later, Cleric Tilena, chief among the dissenters, mocked Anilisia’s efforts. In a cruel display, Tilena reached into the corrupted earth, unearthed the blackened Virathryn seed, and crushed it in her hand. Fearing Anilisia’s wrath, Tilena cast powerful illusions to mask her escape and fled into the wilds."

The chapter ends here. The remaining chapters of this chronicle seem lost to time, their secrets buried with them.

Figworts.name: Figworts
Figworts.description: Figworts are a coveted herb, as a lot of herbalists look for them as they can be of use in curing skin inflammation, pain reliever, or even as a mild laxative. Most Figworts are usually found in rich woodlands, and when the gatherers go into the forest, they attempt to keep an eye out for them, as herbalists tend to pay a premium for them.

Finger Claw.name: Finger Claw
Finger Claw.description: They’re not weapons, despite the way a few swaggering lads like to scratch the air with them. They’re costume, pure and simple, but folk treat them with a strange seriousness. In the riverlands, berry stained claws are handed out to children to mark the turning of the season, while in the port towns you’ll find claws inlaid with bits of colored glass, sold at a premium to visiting merchants who want to blend in with the eccentric nobility.

Fir Log.name: Fir Log
Fir Log.description: The Fir Log is a sturdy and versatile piece of wood, prized for its strength and durability. The logs are cut from the resilient fir trees that grow in the snowy mountains, imbued with their rugged spirit and strength. Because fir wood is strong and durable, it is an ideal material for creating frames and other structural components of a building. In addition to their practical uses, fir planks are also prized for their attractive appearance. The wood has a distinctive light-colored, straight-grain appearance, making it a popular choice for decorative purposes.

Fir Plank.name: Fir Plank
Fir Plank.description: The Fir Plank is a common and versatile building material, used throughout the realms for a wide variety of purposes. It is harvested from tall, straight fir trees that grow in the cool, misty forests of the northern lands. The wood is strong and durable, yet light and easy to work with.

Firework Slime Potion.name: Firework Slime Potion
Firework Slime Potion.description: Labeled clearly "Do not consume" and wear protection when opening on as a small note on the label. It is usually created for special celebrations or for town events.The liquid is quite viscous and as the cap is taken off it starts to harden, it can be molded in any shape. After being opened and having hardened it can be thrown in the air and will accelerate up to 500 feet and then explode in a colorful spectacle that keeps the same shape as the original mold.

Fish Soup.name: Fish Soup
Fish Soup.description: The flavor and character of fish soup are influenced by the type of fish available locally. This dish is a popular choice among commoners for its lightness and delightful taste.

Flat Tongs.name: Flat Tongs
Flat Tongs.description: These particular tongs are available in various shapes, ranging from a slender design crafted for creating small indentations in metals to broader variants designed for handling firey-hot metals. They stand out as some of the most versatile types of tongs, serving the purpose of picking up and gripping hot pieces of flat metal, preferred by most novice blacksmiths.

Flax.name: Flax
Flax.description: It is sometimes referred to as linseed. The flax mainly has two specific uses, to create vegetable oil from the flax seed, or to create textile material from the harvesting of the stem.

Flute.name: Flute
Flute.description: The flute is known for its adaptability, being made from a wide range of materials such as bamboo, jade, glass, blackwood, bone, and various metals. Its light, bright sound has made it a beloved instrument in many cultures, especially in tavern settings where it often forms part of a trio with the lute and harp. Beyond its popularity in taverns, the flute is also widely used in rituals, celebrations, and folk traditions, giving it a strong cultural presence in both formal and informal events across the realms.

Fly Agaric.name: Fly Agaric
Fly Agaric.description: Fly Agaric is sometimes called in dire times "The Graveyard Keeper" due to its toxic proprieties. However, even with warning some do still consume it as it is believed that it makes a connection with the deities with often fatal results. The mushroom's primary use is as an insecticide, when it is combined with milk, it both attracts and kills flies, which also gave it its name.

Fly potion.name: Fly potion
Fly potion.description: Contrary to popular belief this potion does not provide any ability to fly. It is the somewhat unbalanced product of its counterpart that does indeed provide the said ability. This potion does provide the ability to see temporarily up to a distance of 400 ft in full detail, however, the user needs to focus on the specific location and takes a bit of adaption, like the eyes adapting in the dark. This potion can provide a clearer picture of the distance, however, no perception increases are applied.

Fool's Gold.name: Fool's Gold
Fool's Gold.description:
"A few decades ago, there was a quartz mine controlled by its local Thieves’ Guild, at a certain point it struck a huge vein of Iron Pyrite, also known as Fool's Gold. Initially, like everyone else, they did believe it to be gold, but a quick assessment by the blacksmith from the area revealed it wasn’t. Unfortunately, that blacksmith was never to be heard from again. Fast-forward a couple of years, The Thieves Guild manages to replace all jewelry and all coins in the region. Eventually, it reached the lordship, and he sent a battalion to the town... I'm unsure if it still exists, as neither the battalion that was sent nor word of the Thieves’ Guild ever came from that region."

 

Iron Pyrite also known as the Fool's Gold, has limited uses, it is mainly used as a form of ignition in firearms, creating a small spark to ignite the gunpowder. It can also be used with flint as a method of starting fires.

Foraging Backpack.name: Foraging Backpack
Foraging Backpack.description: Crafted from straw and reinforced with light wood like willow, this sturdy basket is perfect for gatherers and herbalists. It’s designed for foraging in woodland areas, by the rivers, or across open fields, providing a lightweight yet durable tool for collecting food and herbs.

Fox Hide.name: Fox Hide
Fox Hide.description: Being quite common in the forested areas, the hide is usually tanned or sold for making clothing, accessories, or crafts, with varieties like red, silver, and arctic fox prized for their thick, soft fur used in coats, hats, gloves, or boots. This is usually brought to the leatherworkers by either commoners or nobles, while having some time for recreation, or by dedicated hunters.

Freshwater Pearl.name: Freshwater Pearl
Freshwater Pearl.description: Freshwater mussels, located in most bodies of water from lakes and ponds to rivers, can produce Pearls. Highly sought after as they can be used for both jewelry and to adorning clothing. In some regions, the Pearls are considered sacred, and any caster that uses  spells that consume them will quickly meet his demise if found out.

Fried Dumplings.name: Fried Dumplings
Fried Dumplings.description: Dumplings are a popular dish made from flour and egg, and filled with meat, fruit, rice, or a combination of these. Bakeries prepare large quantities of dumplings each morning, providing a quick and filling meal for workers heading to the fields or for commoners taking a break.

Fried Fish.name: Fried Fish
Fried Fish.description: Fried fish is often prepared by coating the fish in batter, breadcrumbs, flour, or herbs and spices before frying and serving. It is commonly accompanied by a slice of lemon or greens.

Fried Pumpkin Seeds.name: Fried Pumpkin Seeds
Fried Pumpkin Seeds.description: After fall festivals and fairs, taverns often have leftover pumpkins, and the seeds can be put to good use. The seeds are salted, fried, and served as a tasty snack for tavern patrons.

Fruit Jam.name: Fruit Jam
Fruit Jam.description: Fruit jam is created by combining crushed or chopped fruits with sugar. Various types of fruits, including figs, grapes, peaches, plums, and even lemons, can be transformed into jam. Its versatility is vast, as it can be mixed with dairy products, used as a topping for bread, biscuits, or cakes, or even incorporated into salad dressings.

Fruit Puree.name: Fruit Puree
Fruit Puree.description: This dessert can be made using a variety of fruits available on the market, such as peaches, apples, and strawberries. First, the fruits are peeled, and their seeds and cores are removed. Then, they are boiled until they become soft enough to be mashed. To enhance the flavor, lemon or orange juice is often added to the mixture. This dessert is usually served as a side for most baked goods, as it complements them perfectly. Alternatively, it can be served cold to combat those hot, summer days.

Fruit Vulcano Lava Pie.name: Fruit Vulcano Lava Pie
Fruit Vulcano Lava Pie.description: From the first bite to the last, this pie is a delight. As you pierce the crust with a spoon, the hot fruit jam oozes out, resembling lava, from which it gets its name.

Fustian.name: Fustian
Fustian.description: A heavy cloth woven for clothing, usually used for padding clothes, for colder seasons, or heavy-duty work like building.

Gabbro.name: Gabbro
Gabbro.description: Gabbro, known as black granite in construction terms, serves primarily in building stone fences due to its durability despite its challenging workability. It is mainly extracted for the other minerals found within the same rock, including chromium, nickel, cobalt, copper, gold, silver, and platinum.

Gallows.name: Gallows
Gallows.description: One single upright post with a beam at the top forms the basic structure of the gallows, designed for executing death row inmates guilty of horrendous acts. Beyond punishment, they have served as public displays of justice or, in some cases, as a warning to the people after the unrest, often at the direction of the regional higher class.

Garden Hoe.name: Garden Hoe
Garden Hoe.description: The garden hoe serves multiple purposes, assisting with seeding by creating small trenches for seed placement and aiding in weed removal. With its sharp and wide blade, farmers favor the garden hoe for cutting rows of weeds. It effortlessly slides just beneath the soil's surface, cutting the roots of pesky weeds.

Garlic.name: Garlic
Garlic.description: The most used spice in the majority of dishes. Cooked, sliced, diced, minced, or even boiled, if it is a cooked dish, it most likely has a pinch of garlic in it.

Garlic Scapes.name: Garlic Scapes
Garlic Scapes.description: Garlic scapes are an herb with a stronger garlicky flavor than common chives. They are primarily used for pickling or seeding and are rarely used in cooking or as a stir-fry base for scrambled eggs. In some regions, garlic scapes are considered a seasonal delicacy, eagerly awaited each spring. Local markets fill with bundles of these curly green stalks, signaling the start of warmer months and inspiring cooks to add a unique twist to traditional recipes.

Garum.name: Garum
Garum.description: Garum is a sauce made primarily from fish. In some areas, it bears the simple name of fish sauce or liquamen. However, liquamen, throughout the eras, evolved into a different type of sauce. The original garum recipe was created through the fermentation of fish remnants with coarse salt, yielding a dark, aromatic sauce of notable culinary significance, to which spices can be added to most meats or mussels.

Gauze.name: Gauze
Gauze.description: Primarily made out from linen, its main purpose is cleaning injureies. To help in this, some antiseptics like honey or vinegar are used with these cloths for bandaging, and sometimes medicinal herbs are incorporated to speed up the healing process. Most travelers have a few premade with them at all times.

Gear.name: Gear
Gear.description: An regular gear piece that fits into everything mechanized, from clocks to doors to pressure valves, it is a specialized tool for all mechanized items and structures. Without it, they would not exist. Primarily made out of copper, brass, or bronze, it resists rust and lasts for decades.

Geelbeck Croaker.name: Geelbeck Croaker
Geelbeck Croaker.description: Geelbeck Croakers are commonly found in offshore waters, gathering around reefs, wrecks, and sandy bottoms. They are easy to catch in large numbers using small fish like sardines or herring as bait. Their mild, flavorful meat makes them a favorite by chefs, prepared in various ways from baking to stir-frying.

Gem Encrusted Crown.name: Gem Encrusted Crown
Gem Encrusted Crown.description: A crown fit for a king. Usually crafted by a jeweler with a diverse set of skills, such as silversmithing, goldsmithing, and gemcutting, and often honored with the distinguished title of Crown Jeweler by the populace. He is also responsible for maintaining each piece of royal jewelry, ensuring it remains in pristine condition every time it is worn.

Gem Encrusted Polyhedral Dice.name: Gem Encrusted Polyhedral Dice
Gem Encrusted Polyhedral Dice.description: An encrusted dice set, typically containing multiple die types. Artisans carve elegant dice sets from luminous albite, inlaying each die with copper bindings to fortify its edges. These sets are usually accompanied by story-driven games played by commoners. Some of the more famous titles include the "Explorer" series as well as multiple editions of "Duties and Divinities" currently sitting at it's seventh edition.

Ghast.name: Ghast
Ghast.description: Ghast holds cultural significance as a beverage that draws inspiration from local folklore and ghost stories. It serves not only as a drink but also as a storytelling device, connecting people to the eerie tales whispered during the night. The unique coloring comes from the help of alchemists which add butterfly pea flower that shifts color in acidity. The drink itself is quite versatile as it can be drunk standalone, used as a cocktail base, or kept as a collector's item.

Giant's Greens Pie.name: Giant's Greens Pie
Giant's Greens Pie.description: This pie is made with multiple types of cheese, as well as onions, spinach, and garlic. It is a common recipe in both households and bakeries due to its delicious and filling nature. Legends have it that the pie is so satisfying that it can even sate giants. In the past, it was even given as a gesture of goodwill to these somewhat misunderstood creatures.

Ginger.name: Ginger
Ginger.description: Ginger, is widely used as a spice and folk medicine. It is provided as tea for those who have weak stomachs to combat nausea, among other things.

Glass.name: Glass
Glass.description: The process of shaping glass is time-consuming, and to create it, glassblowers need a vast amount of skill. After the glassblowing process is completed and the glass is still hot, it is placed into molds to create bottles, vials, windows, and other glass objects such as vases or decorative objects.

Glazed Fruits.name: Glazed Fruits
Glazed Fruits.description: The selection of fruits for this delightful sweet can vary, depending on what's available at the morning market that the bakery frequents, in some rare cases even fruits that were conjured by magic. While any fresh fruit can be used, apples are the most commonly chosen option due to their ease of baking. However, it's not unheard of for bakers to use any other types of fruits, such as oranges, grapes, and even wild sweet berries, to add an extra burst of flavor. After the fruits are baked the baker carefully applies a glaze made from a mixture of honey and high-quality jam, or the higher priced chocolate by request, with the target audience ranging from young children to adults with a sweet tooth.

Gleaming Unicorn.name: Gleaming Unicorn
Gleaming Unicorn.description: When forest folk attempt to create new forest circles, they use a form of primal magic to extract all the metals from the ground, and with the precious metals they dig out, they create coins. These coins are an alloy between platinum and silver making them a quite valuable commodity and used for trade when they go into civilization. Their value is roughly 25% of platinum.

Glider Wings.name: Glider Wings
Glider Wings.description: While few understand the intricate workings of aerodynamics, some who do use a pair of semi-mechanized wings to travel faster than on foot. They are usually made from a very light aluminum frame with strengthened cloth, similar to that used on the largest ship sails.

Gloves of Working.name: Gloves of Working
Gloves of Working.description: Gloves were worn by outdoor workers for practical purposes, such as gardening or heavy outdoor work. These working gloves were often made of leather and lined with fur, or alternatively, made of sheepskin with the fleece on the inside.

Gneiss.name: Gneiss
Gneiss.description: Gneiss has many uses as a building material such as flooring, ornamental stones, gravestones, facing stones on buildings, and work surfaces. Depending on where is acquired, it can have beautiful patterns making it one of the most sought-after types of materials for ornamental construction.

Goat.name: Goat
Goat.description: Goats have been utilized for milk, meat, fur, and skins across most of the realms. Goat milk is often processed into goat cheese, and farmers sell it at a premium. The hide and fabric are perfect for making gloves, shoes, and other accessories, making it a favorite for leatherworkers.

God's Wrath.name: God's Wrath
God's Wrath.description: Sometimes called Brimstone, and more commonly known as Sulfur. Alchemists usually use blocks of sulfur in creating potent acids that can burn through anything. It is often at the center of disputes between alchemical and religious groups, as by some religions it is believed to be sacred, given how it burns in a unique color with the flames a rich purple shade. Alchemists however advise against burning the blocks as they believe that doing so can inflict irreparable damage to one's health. Herbalists use it to create multiple types of green dyes.

Gold Bangle.name: Gold Bangle
Gold Bangle.description: Gold Bangle is a bracelet crafted from pure gold, designed to symbolize the highest class of nobility and the pinnacle of societal status. Forged by skilled blacksmiths using precise molds, each piece is then handed over to renowned goldsmiths who meticulously finish it with ornate detailing. These bangles are typically priced highly, which makes them frequent targets for thieves and swindlers seeking to profit from their value.

Gold Ingot.name: Gold Ingot
Gold Ingot.description: Gold Ingots serve as the most common currency among merchants and nobles, valued for their purity and ease of transport. Jewelers also look for them as the metal is without impurities and is preferable to make bands, bracelets, or necklaces encrusted with gems. Some kingdoms even use the ingots to secure treaties and fund military campaigns, ensuring their armies remain well-equipped and loyal.

Gold Key.name: Gold Key
Gold Key.description: To instill additional trust in the owners of safety deposit boxes across the realms, some banks commission keys for their boxes to be crafted from gold, projecting an image of prestige and wealth. However, these so-called gold keys are often fashioned from pyrite, a far less durable material. Over time and with regular use, these pyrite keys tend to snap or crumble, while the banks cutting costs.

Golden Berry.name: Golden Berry
Golden Berry.description: The cape gooseberry is sometimes referred to as either ground cherry or golden berry, due to its yellow color. Most of the time, it is eaten as is or dipped in sweet chocolate. It can also be cooked to make exquisite jams, jellies, and purées, or used in exotic fruit salads, pavlovas, and roulades. Additionally, it can be simmered in water with a little sugar and used in fruit pies, cakes, or crumbles.

Golden Deer.name: Golden Deer
Golden Deer.description: When the forest folk finishes their druidic circles, a lot of precious metals they create coins from the alloys, from platinum and silver, as well gold and copper. The gold and copper alloy is named tumbaga, and in the bigger cities, they are commonly referred to as Tumbaga coins. They are worth roughly 25% of the gold's value. They are referred to as Deers or Elk, as it is the most common imprint on these coins.

Golden Encrusted Goblet.name: Golden Encrusted Goblet
Golden Encrusted Goblet.description: Throughout history and in certain fringe regions of the realms, goblets served as a symbol of status and refinement. Alchemists and herbalists have long warned against drinking alcohol from gold goblets, as the metal can react with the contents and produce toxic effects. Today, such goblets are most often discovered in forgotten tombs or among the hoards of exotic collectors, winged or otherwise.

Goldilocks.name: Goldilocks
Goldilocks.description: Goldilocks captivates the palate with a harmony of bright fruit notes and gentle malt undertones. Each sip reveals layers of flavor that unfold gradually, appealing to beer enthusiasts who seek depth and nuance rather than a simple, familiar taste.

Gong.name: Gong
Gong.description: The gong is a flat, circular metal disc typically struck with a mallet. It is prudced out of bronze, brass, or iron and is suspended on a stand. Gongs do vary in size, from small to large, and can either be pre-tuned or require manual tuning. As an instrument, the gong has multiple uses, ranging from opera performances to serving as a signal device in various settings, such as for events like fights or races, or even as alarms.

Good Luck Potion No. 12.name: Good Luck Potion No. 12
Good Luck Potion No. 12.description: A potion recipe that supposedly makes one quite lucky with just one sip. While the actual effectiveness of the potion is debatable, the recipe has already undergone eleven different revisions. It's rather popular among the nobility.

Gooseberry.name: Gooseberry
Gooseberry.description: The gooseberry plant, while adored by wildlife, plays a critical role as both a food source and a vector for disease. Its berries provide essential nutrients for many animals, including birds and bears, who rely on the fruit for sustenance during the summer months. However, its rapid spread also means that it is often seen as an invasive threat to local flora, particularly coniferous trees like pines, which can suffer long-term damage from the blister rust fungus it harbors.

Goulash.name: Goulash
Goulash.description: Goulash is a hearty stew made with various cuts of meat, onions, and paprika, simmered slowly in a cauldron over low heat. Typically, it is prepared to be quite spicy, perfect for enjoying with a side dish like mashed potatoes.

Grain Leather.name: Grain Leather
Grain Leather.description: Usually referring to full-grain leather, it is the highest quality leather, made from the top layer of the animal skin with its natural grain and imperfections, like scars, wrinkles, or hair follicles, left intact, making it incredibly durable, strong, and capable of developing a beautiful patina over time, unlike lower-grade leathers that are sanded or buffed.

Grandfather Clock.name: Grandfather Clock
Grandfather Clock.description: Grandfather clock, also known as a longcase clock, tall-case clock, hall clock, or floor clock, is a tall, freestanding, weight-driven pendulum clock with the pendulum held inside the tower or waist of the case. These are created by the most experienced woodworkers, with help from specialized engineers.

Granite.name: Granite
Granite.description: Granite is a common rock that comes in various colors, such as white, dark-gray, and brown. Because of its range of colors, it's often cut into shapes for gravestones, memorials, and pavement. Its durability and low maintenance needs make it a suitable choice for these uses.

Grapefruit.name: Grapefruit
Grapefruit.description: Herbalists usually warn against consuming grapefruit or grapefruit juice, when taking medicines, as the medicine provided might not work as intended. The grapefruit is also a known popular breakfast fruit for the nobility.

Grapes.name: Grapes
Grapes.description: Most of the Grape production is used for Wine, and most if not all taverns or inns have long-lasting contracts with vineyards. They come in multiple colors like crimson, black, dark blue, yellow, green, orange, pink, and purple. They can also be used for jams or dried and turned into raisins which are then used in cooking, most often pastries.

Gravestone.name: Gravestone
Gravestone.description: Gravestones as when it comes with Red Harvest's nature, oddly enough, aren't just decorative. I’ve found that wherever these grave markers are set, the ground beneath has a curious habit of stirring, like it is calling. More than one caretaker in Bacau's Letea District swears that a cheap plaster marker is just as likely to hide a restless corpse as the real thing. Some scholars argue it’s all coincidence or that the Red Harvest festival simply draws out the necromantic residue that lingers in cities from the countless wars.

Great Forest Rolls.name: Great Forest Rolls
Great Forest Rolls.description: They are filled with a mixture of fresh cabbage, savory mushrooms, and fragrant dill, while the dough sheet is expertly combined with crunchy salted almonds for added texture and flavor. Additionally, for those who prefer a sweeter twist, a version with honeydew melon, refreshing cucumber, and aromatic basil and mint leaves is available, with the dough sheet and almonds glazed with sweet honey for extra flavor.

Green Apple.name: Green Apple
Green Apple.description: Innkeepers use green apples to garnish some of their beverages, as well as, provide it as a healthy desert variant. Famous ciders are made from green apples throughout the realms, therefore inn and tavern keepers have green apples in high demand.

Green Breeze Ear Piece.name: Green Breeze Ear Piece
Green Breeze Ear Piece.description: This emerald-gemmed earpiece is designed for those who wish to convey their place among the upper class. It is an exceptionally expensive fashion accessory, though many find it uncomfortable to wear. The piece must be positioned on specific parts of the ear, which can be outright painful for some individuals whose ear shape does not accommodate its specific design fit.

Green Gauntlet.name: Green Gauntlet
Green Gauntlet.description: The boldness of Green Gauntlet mirrors the bravery of the knights it honors. Its sharp, invigorating flavors awaken the senses, providing a burst of courage with every sip. The combination of herbs and spices used in the brew creates a complex taste that lingers, much like the valor of a steadfast protector.

Green Grapes.name: Green Grapes
Green Grapes.description: The fruit makes a popular snack, both because of its sweet flavor and because you can eat it whole without making a mess. Vineyards use the highest quality form of the green grape to make the most pristine white wines.

Green Olive.name: Green Olive
Green Olive.description: Green olives are picked when they have grown to full size, while still unripe. They can usually be found in shades from green to yellow. Olives are usually fermented to preserve them for a longer period of time and they generally end up being eaten as a healthy snack.

Green Pepper.name: Green Pepper
Green Pepper.description: The bell pepper usually comes in multiple colors, mainly green, yellow, and red, but purple, pink or white are not uncommon either. They are mainly referred to as sweet peppers. They can be garnished on multiple dishes, however, the most common use they have is in salads as an ingredient

Green Salad.name: Green Salad
Green Salad.description: The green salad is made from locally available vegetables, including onions, cucumbers, radishes, lettuce, spinach, and cabbage, among others.

Green Shadow.name: Green Shadow
Green Shadow.description: A butchered product of incorrectly mixing any potion that provides a form of invisibility. The skin starts to go chameleonic to a form, changing color to match its suroundings, however, the effect is slow to set in and it takes a bit of time up until you're fully "blended" with your background.

Green Soldier Bug.name: Green Soldier Bug
Green Soldier Bug.description: Green Soldier Bug, commonly referred to as the stink bug, emits a foul odor when crushed and poses a serious threat to crops like aubergines and tomatoes. Fortunately, unlike the Green Summer beetle, this critter can be managed effectively by hens and ducks, which help control their numbers without harming any of the crop.

Green Summer Beetle.name: Green Summer Beetle
Green Summer Beetle.description: Green Summer beetles become a problem during the growing season, harming both gardens and crops. These beetles target ripe or fermenting fruits like figs, grapes, and berries. Every summer, many common folk try to include wormwood in their planting cycle as it mostly behaves as an insect repellent.

Grilled Ribs.name: Grilled Ribs
Grilled Ribs.description: Fall-off-the-bone ribs, coated in sweet and tangy homemade sauces, are a beloved favorite at most taverns, often served for events or celebrations, and eagerly enjoyed by adventurers returning triumphant from their quests or missions.

Grilled Steak.name: Grilled Steak
Grilled Steak.description: A meticulously cooked slice of premium meat, often beef, cooked with precision and often with a side by your choice of fresh greens or soft mashed potatoes.

Grinder.name: Grinder
Grinder.description: A wooden contraption made with finely crafted and durable iron cogwheels is designed to reduce materials into a fine powder. A crank allows for easy operation. Though it originally served as an alternative to the traditional mortar and pestle, it is now primarily used by taverns to quickly grind dried pepper.

Grog.name: Grog
Grog.description: Grog is basically rum diluted with water. During expeditions to newly found lands, ship captains water down barrels of rum to keep the crew content while stretching their limited supplies over an extended period. This approach helped maintain high morale on long voyages where fresh provisions were scarce.

Hair Pin.name: Hair Pin
Hair Pin.description: A designer hairpin crafted with small gemstones to represent high status. It is made in such a way that, when it holds the hair, it exudes elegance and style, or to simply signal membership in the high noble class. These are primarily made by experienced jewelers and only on very high-priced commissions.

Hambergite.name: Hambergite
Hambergite.description: Hambergite is typically colorless or faintly blue. Despite being categorized as a semi-precious gem, it is more valued for its applications in lighting. It is commonly used in lamps to enhance the brightness of candles and other light sources, whether they are conventional or by arcane means.

Hand Axe.name: Hand Axe
Hand Axe.description: The go-to axe for various applications, it proves its usefulness as a camping tool for felling small trees, splitting kindling, and preparing firewood. Craftsmen appreciate its finesse in cutting wood to size and creating intricate patterns on furniture.

Hand Cart.name: Hand Cart
Hand Cart.description: The all-round tool for transporting items where they are needed. It can be used to transport feed for animals, large objects like planks, or carry fruits from orchards, all while remaining lightweight, making it a must-have tool on most farms.

Hand Drill.name: Hand Drill
Hand Drill.description: Functioning as a manual tool, a hand drill transforms and magnifies the circular motion of the crank into the rotation of a drill chuck. The tool includes a cranking handle that turns pinion gears on the main shaft, with a chuck at the end designed to secure a drill bit. This versatile tool finds common use among masons, carpenters, leatherworkers, and even blacksmiths, facilitating the drilling of fine holes in hard materials such as wood, hard leather, stone, soft metals, or even bones.

Hand Saw.name: Hand Saw
Hand Saw.description: With a wide range of applications, hand saws are the go-to tools for tasks like roughly cutting wood and logs, as well as making intricate curved cuts in wood. Whether used in professional trades or by the commoner for projects at home or in the garden, they prove to be indispensable tools.

Hand Truck.name: Hand Truck
Hand Truck.description: A hand truck, also referred to as a hand cart, comes with long handles is perfect for moving heavy items like barrels and furniture. It is frequently used by inns, taverns, and bakeries to facilitate daily restocking from the market.

Hard Candy.name: Hard Candy
Hard Candy.description: Hard candy has traditionally been regarded as a form of medicine, provided by herbalists to soothe stomach pains or alleviate sore throats. However, in more recent times, additional sugar and fruit have been incorporated into its recipe, quickly making it a favorite among young commoners.

Hardtack.name: Hardtack
Hardtack.description: Hardtack, made from flour, water, and salt, is known for its long shelf life. Due to its affordability and durability, it serves as a staple sustenance during long sea voyages and military campaigns, where most other foods are scarce.

Harunite.name: Harunite
Harunite.description: Hambergite is typically colorless or faintly blue. Despite being categorized as a semi-precious gem, it is more valued for its applications in lighting. It is commonly used in lamps to enhance the brightness of candles and other light sources, whether they are conventional or by arcane means.

Hazelnut.name: Hazelnut
Hazelnut.description: Hazelnuts get their name from their color, hazel. Sometimes they are also referred to as cobnuts or filberts. The nuts are used in cakes or as crumble toppings, however, if grounded they can also be used as flour for baking.

Heart.name: Heart
Heart.description: Looks like a stage prop, doesn’t it? Too shiny, too perfect, the sort of thing you’d expect dangling from a street conjurer’s sleeve. Yet hold one in your palm and you’ll swear it thrums against your skin, slow, steady, like the echo of your own chest. I’ve seen hardened mercenaries drop the thing lika a curse, as if they’d grabbed a live rat.

Hellgrammite.name: Hellgrammite
Hellgrammite.description: Hellgrammites are the perfect fishing bait across the realms, known to attract a wide range of fish including panfish, perch, pickerel, channel catfish, and especially bass. When fishing in deeper water or near heavy structures like submerged logs, tree roots, large rocks, or boat docks, they are thought to be particularly successful at drawing in the big catches, however, quite intimidating to look at.

Hematite.name: Hematite
Hematite.description: It is usually found with iron veins. Depending on its color when mined, it's mainly used to make red and brown pigments. On rare occasions, it is used for magical purposes, as it is assumed that this gem is linked to blood and life force. Used in the healing arts and necromancy

Henbane.name: Henbane
Henbane.description: The Henbane, also known as the Witches Plant, is a highly toxic plant, similar to the nightshade, however, herbalists use it, in combination with a plethora of other plants, to create anesthetic for sale for any medical practitioners. The Henbane is also a ritualistic herb, being used by magicians and healers in ritual purifications by smoke as well as in the preparation of concoctions, love philters, and 'flying ointments'.

Herring.name: Herring
Herring.description: Herrings can be fished in a variety of ways, from setting bait directly in the water and using nets to capture them in large batches, to more traditional rod fishing. Once caught, herrings are stored in numerous ways, with regional recipes that include raw, fermented, pickled, or salted varieties, as well as smoked or preserved through other methods.

Hexagonite.name: Hexagonite
Hexagonite.description: Hexagonite is an interesting gemstone, distinguished by its hexagonal shape when unearthed, which inspired its name. These gems are often sewn into clothing for social events, symbolically representing eligibility for marriage, particularly for bachelors.

Hickory Log.name: Hickory Log
Hickory Log.description: One of the most sought after types of wood. Used in most construction projects.

Hickory Plank.name: Hickory Plank
Hickory Plank.description: This specific light-colored wood is widely used for tools like hammers, picks, axes, wheels, ladders, flooring, and furniture.

Hog.name: Hog
Hog.description: Referred to as the hog, more commonly known as pig or sow in husbandry, this animal holds a prominent position as one of the most farmed for its meat. It serves as a vital resource in the production of sausages, gammon, bacon, ham, and various other food items.

Homemade Counteractant.name: Homemade Counteractant
Homemade Counteractant.description: Some of the commoners use quite a bit of lemon in creating these solutions, with other materials that they can find, which in return might have some adverse reactions. Sometimes leading to blindness or skin diseases after the concoction explodes or has other unforeseen and unfortunate side-effects, however, it's still common practice to create your own as the price for a store bought one is usually outside what a regular commoner can afford. Alchemists try to provide warnings of these issues, however, they mostly fall on deaf ears.

Honey.name: Honey
Honey.description: Honey, the sweet and viscous substance produced by honey bees, is commonly cultivated by many monasteries. Stored within the hive, honey bees construct honeycomb structures made from wax to contain the honey. Additionally, beeswax candles, derived from the honeycomb, are frequently used for lighting homes.

Honey Cookies.name: Honey Cookies
Honey Cookies.description: These types of cookies, made with honey, tend to have a fluffier texture and sweeter taste. Due to their affordability, filling nature, and extended shelf life, most taverns keep them in stock for sale at all times.

Honeycomb Cake.name: Honeycomb Cake
Honeycomb Cake.description: Despite its name, the Honeycomb Cake does not contain any honey. However, most bakers shape it into a honeycomb pattern to enhance its appeal. Due to its exotic ingredients, this cake remains unfamiliar to many commoners. It requires pandan, coconut milk, and coconut oil, which can be difficult to find depending on the region.

Horn.name: Horn
Horn.description: The horn is often regarded as the predecessor to both the trumpet and the cornet. While it is primarily made from brass, there are also variants crafted from bone, which are particularly favored in remote, cold, or mountainous regions. They can be used for music, drive for battles, or alarms.

Horseshoe.name: Horseshoe
Horseshoe.description: In certain regions, horseshoes are seen as a harbinger of good luck, while in others, they symbolize advanced industry. Typically crafted from steel, the choice of material may vary depending on metal availability in specific areas, including options like bronze, copper, or iron. In exceptionally uncommon cases, materials such as hide, leather, or even wood are considered.

Horsetail.name: Horsetail
Horsetail.description: Horsetail is a common herb that has been used by herbalists for centuries to treat a variety of ailments, including bleeding, wounds, colds, and hay fever. It grows in many parts of the world and is considered poisonous to sheep and cattle, although it is safe for the common folk to consume in small amounts.

Hosho.name: Hosho
Hosho.description: The hosho is a rattle instrument crafted from a wild orange known as damba, with sticks used to tie it together and filled with hota seeds or pebbles. Its unique shape produces a sharp, distinctive sound that often cuts through the music of other instruments.

Hot Punch.name: Hot Punch
Hot Punch.description: Referred to either as a forging punch or hot punch, this tool is primarily utilized for cutting or punching through metal to shape and secure it. Moreover, it lends itself to forming impressions or designs, making it a choice for the more discerning customers.

Hot Spiced Raspberry Cider.name: Hot Spiced Raspberry Cider
Hot Spiced Raspberry Cider.description: Considered by most a traditional winter drink with the sweet addition of fruit. Its inviting aroma will fill the taverns, while the warm cider keeps everyone cozy during cold season evenings. Although multiple ingredients can be used in its making, two remain constant, mainly rum and raspberry cider. Additions such as maple syrup, cardamom, ginger, peppercorns, cloves, or cinnamon are common additions that give it a stronger flavor and seasonal charm.

Hugger of Faces.name: Hugger of Faces
