Silver Pearl.name: Silver Pearl
Silver Pearl.description: Even if it's referred to as silver, it usually bears a green tint based on the biome it was harvested from. Mainly used by alchemists to create potions that improve the user's attention and survival skills.

Silver Ring.name: Silver Ring
Silver Ring.description: Silver rings tend to serve primarily as fashion statements, often chosen to complement specific outfits through visual coordination. They are also worn by individuals who are allergic to certain metals or by those seeking a more affordable option when purchasing new jewelry.

Silver Winter.name: Silver Winter
Silver Winter.description: This coin is a symbol of achievement and status within the bardic colleges. After successfully completing their last year of college, attendees are given a copper coin crafted by art students, featuring intricate seasonal markings. The coin is also available in other patterns, such as Silver Solar, Snow, or Summer, each corresponding to a different season. Despite its name, the coin is made of copper and holds a value similar to that of a silver piece.

Sinhalite.name: Sinhalite
Sinhalite.description: Sinhalite, occurring naturally, manifests as yellow gemstones resembling rounded pebbles, shaped by the tumbling action of water in active streams or dried-up riverbeds.

Skewers.name: Skewers
Skewers.description: Meats and vegetables are sliced or cubed before being threaded onto a skewer one by one and cooked. The mingling of juices between the meats and vegetables creates a unique and flavorful taste.

Skipjack Tuna.name: Skipjack Tuna
Skipjack Tuna.description: Skipjack are the smallest and most abundant of the tuna species. For bait, live fish such as herring, mackerel, or squid are preferred. Their streamlined, mostly scale-free bodies make them ideal for long-term preservation through salting, smoking, or pickling.

Skull Candle.name: Skull Candle
Skull Candle.description: Tavern-keeps and innholders are their primary patrons. They are cheap to buy and cheaper to maintain, and they give a place a certain... character. I also must say, they are particularly fond of them, claiming the grim visage keeps rowdy dockhands in their seats. I find they are more often used as a target for throwing knives after the seventh round of ale, but for one night a year, I think the keeps can manage.

Skull Ring.name: Skull Ring
Skull Ring.description: While a staple for the Red Harvest, wear one long enough and folk assume you’ve done something grim, as I forgot to take it of for a few. I wore one for a fortnight on the in a runty village while traveling, just to see, and the dockhands and farmers alike, gave me a wide berth, muttering that I must’ve lost a crew to the deep, or that something horrible has happened to me.

Sky Blue.name: Sky Blue
Sky Blue.description: The small mushroom is a distinctive all-blue color, in some places called Werewere-kokako, due to its similar coloring to the Kokako bird. Its beauty is deceptive, for its poison brings swift death to those who dare to eat it. For the skilled artisan, it offers something different, a blue dye so rich and rare to be used for ordinary cloth to transform it into a work of art.

Slate.name: Slate
Slate.description:
"Slate doesn't get the love it deserves. Most writing boards are made out of it, also, it is quite resistant if cut into shapes and made into shingles"

Slate comes in many colors, from shades of gray to green to purple, even cyan depending on where it was harvested. It's mainly used in writing tablets and roofing.

Sled.name: Sled
Sled.description: Sleds are designed in various shapes and sizes to accommodate various scenarios. They range from children's sleds, perfect for racing down large hills, to sturdy traveling sleds used by sled dogs to traverse vast winter landscapes.

Sleep Tincture.name: Sleep Tincture
Sleep Tincture.description: When the regular work hands are haunted by sleepless nights, one of the most common ways to get the issue resolved, is with a trusty sleep tincture that is brewed by the Alchemists. It does bear a sweetened taste and the users, after consuming it, can get a good night's rest.

Small Cabbage Sprouts.name: Small Cabbage Sprouts
Small Cabbage Sprouts.description: Different regions have their own names for small cabbage sprouts, usually based on where they are found. Chefs in small restaurants and cooks in local taverns often make a special effort to find these sprouts. Because they are somewhat rare, dishes made with them are typically way more expensive. Some good examples include mixed cabbage salads or caramelized cabbage sprouts.

Smith's Coin.name: Smith's Coin
Smith's Coin.description: When a customer places a custom order or commission at a specialty shop, such as a jewelry store or blacksmith, a coin bearing the shop's symbol is provided. The customer's name is etched on the back of the coin, and they are asked to sign a ledger. Once the item has been crafted or procured, the owner can retrieve it by trading in the coin. The value of the coin is equivalent to the cost of the commissioned item. If the coin is lost or stolen, it becomes worthless, and only the rightful owner can retrieve the item using the original coin.

Smithsonite.name: Smithsonite
Smithsonite.description: Smithsonite, also referred to as zinc spar, is frequently discovered in zinc ore deposits. In earlier eras, it was believed to possess the remarkable ability to restore sight to the blind, though the ancient methods for achieving this feat have faded into obscurity. Modern alchemists persist in their quest to uncover and revive these lost arts.

Smoked Meats.name: Smoked Meats
Smoked Meats.description: The most common method of smoking meats involves using hardwoods like oak, hickory, cherry, or acacia, either individually or in combination. These woods impart distinct flavors to the meat while also aiding in its preservation. Inside the smokehouse, the meat is hung on hooks above a drip tray. Common smoked products include bacon, fish, ham, sausages, salami, and pastrami, each offering a unique taste and flavor.

Snapping Death Worm.name: Snapping Death Worm
Snapping Death Worm.description: Snapping Death Worm, or simply called Bobbit, is an subterranean critter that burrows mostly on beaches, however, every recolection of him resembles a horror story. It senses vibrations on the surface to ambush prey, launching itself upward to drag creatures underground with its snapping jaws.

Soot.name: Soot
Soot.description: Deep black powder or flaky substance, produced by burning material. Used by alchemists and herbalists as a binding agent, and by the weavers as dyes for a plethora of textiles.

Sour Cherry.name: Sour Cherry
Sour Cherry.description: Directly harvested from the tree, Sour Cherries can be delicious when spooned into one's mouth. However, some may find it an acquired taste. The concentrated and juicy result is perfect for pairing with alcoholic beverages, custard, pies, or pudding.

Spade.name: Spade
Spade.description: The spade is perfect for planting and transplanting, spades feature a flat head design that is particularly effective for digging holes or extracting plants from the ground.

Spessartite.name: Spessartite
Spessartite.description: Spessartine is commonly found in deposits alongside Morion, often occurring in substantial quantities. Ancient lore recounts its use in forging full suits of armor, a feat attributed to skilled gem cutters with arcane knowledge

Sphene.name: Sphene
Sphene.description: Sphene is known for its soft and brittle nature, found in shades ranging from yellow to deep green, with the prized emerald green hue being the most sought-after. Its crystals are often cut into dazzling faceted gems of small to medium size.

Spicebush.name: Spicebush
Spicebush.description: The Northern Lindera, infamous as an invasive species, is swiftly dealt with by herbalists who seek to protect local ecosystems. Yet, its fruit finds its way into kitchens, where it is appreciated as a flavorful seasoning for meats, soups, and hearty dishes, to the discontent of the herbalists.

Spider Beetle.name: Spider Beetle
Spider Beetle.description: While the Spider Beetle is harmless to people, spotting it near granaries are problematic. They feed on the dried food supplies, particularly grains and fruits, seeing it, usually, it shows that stored provisions have gone bad.

Spider Silk.name: Spider Silk
Spider Silk.description: Spider silk is highly valued and expensive, despite being a relatively abundant resource. Few people attempt to gather it due to the challenges involved. Although it sells for a high price, silk from larger spiders is usually a bit less costly. The harvesting process involves stunning the spiders and using a specialized extractor to collect the silk.

Spider's Silk.name: Spider's Silk
Spider's Silk.description: This coin is predominantly made of gold, but its color may vary depending on the region where it was mined. It can appear either red or green and is commonly known as Red Gold or Green Gold, respectively. The gold used to create these coins is primarily sourced by underground folk and is mainly used for trade on the surface. The coin features intricate spider carvings on both sides, which has led to its nickname, "Spider Gold" or "Spider Silk."

Spinach.name: Spinach
Spinach.description: Its leaves are a common edible vegetable consumed fresh, stir-fried, or steamed. Herbalists use wine fortified with spinach juice to give to the injured with the intent of reducing or stopping bleeding.

Spindle.name: Spindle
Spindle.description: Commonly made from either wood, bone or metal, the spindle is a rod for spinning wool, silk, and other natural fibers. Among weavers and tailors, it stands out as one of their most cherished tools.

Spinning Wheel.name: Spinning Wheel
Spinning Wheel.description: A spinning wheel, or spindle, is a mechanical device used for spinning thread or yarn from fibers. It converts raw materials such as wool or cotton into usable thread through a process of twisting and winding, which is integral to fabric creation.

Spirit Lights.name: Spirit Lights
Spirit Lights.description: Well now's the Spirit Lights, and encounter that I don't wish. I’ve seen them twice in my travels, and that’s twice too many if you ask me. They look harmless at first, little flickers drifting through the dusk, not larger than fireflies. But the veterans of the harvest know better. Those lights don’t flit about all year. They only show themselves during the Red Harvest, when the moons line up and the fields glow crimson under their light. Stay out in the rows too long chasing one, and something follows. I’ve heard the screams in the night, thin and distant.

Spring Water.name: Spring Water
Spring Water.description: Spring water is collected from underground springs and is mainly used by alchemists. It is highly sought after, and with the help of magical casters, the water is purified even further as it is generally used to create potions. Magical water streams are rare yet when found it is speculated that the potion created using this specific type of water highly increases its potency.

Squash.name: Squash
Squash.description: Gourds, Pumpkins, and Zucchini are types of squashes, and they are used in multiple culinary recipes, squash is often roasted, boiled, or steamed. It is usually served with butter or olive oil and savory seasonings, it also counts as an ingredient for sweet bread.

Star Anise.name: Star Anise
Star Anise.description: The Star Anise is not only valued for its flavor but also for its medicinal and aromatic properties, helping with those with heart conditions. In cooking, the whole pods release their flavor gradually, making them ideal for slow-cooked dishes, while ground star anise is a main ingredient in spice mixtures such as the five-spice powder, giving dishes a sweet and spicy taste.

Star Rose Quartz.name: Star Rose Quartz
Star Rose Quartz.description: Or simply known as Rose Quartz, is a pink gemstone mainly used in jewelry. The large slabs can be cut into multiple shapes from hearts, for holidays and anniversaries to huge round shapes, for wizards' crystal balls. It can also be used as a magical material, to deflect spells.

Stargazer Lily.name: Stargazer Lily
Stargazer Lily.description:
"As dusk falls and the night sky begins to darken, there’s a sense of anticipation in the air. Those who know the legend watch the sky closely, waiting for the first signs of a meteor shower. At that very moment, the Stargazer Lily begins to bloom, its petals unfolding as if responding to the celestial display above. The sweet scent fills the air, carrying with it the magic of the stars as if the flower itself has been touched by the heavens."

The Stargazer Lily, known for its fragrance, is grown and harvested in various regions to create perfumes. Some believe that the flower blooms only during a meteor shower, adding a mystical element to its already enchanting nature.

Steel.name: Steel
Steel.description:
"Well, the building block of life, or so they say. I do love its glimmer in the night, especially when guardsmen wear their polished armors, keeps me safe, you know?"

Created from slabs of iron ore in high heat furnaces with added charcoal, it creates one of the sturdiest metals for weaponry. Steel is used mainly in cutlery, inexpensive rings, armor, and weaponry.

Stibiotantalite.name: Stibiotantalite
Stibiotantalite.description: Stibiotantalite is primarily valued as a gemstone, known for its vivid, shiny, golden-brown appearance. It was commonly worn by merchants and mid-level courtiers as an affordable alternative to more expensive gemstones.

Stitch-me-up Pie.name: Stitch-me-up Pie
Stitch-me-up Pie.description: These pies show up most often in autumn markets, when bakers want to flaunt their skill as much as their orchard’s bounty. The more intricate the “stitching,” the higher the price. In my travels, a while back, I once saw a baker take commissions from adventuring companies, shaping pies with gashes that matched their battle scars. Silly? Absolutely. But the guildsmen paid handsomely, and everyone left sticky-fingered and grinning.

Stone Brick.name: Stone Brick
Stone Brick.description: The stone brick is often expensive to produce, as it requires specialized tools and skilled craftsmen or masons to shape and polish, as well, and must be mined from deep within the earth or quarried from rock formations, making it often reserved for the most prestigious building projects, such as castles, walls, forts, and fortresses.

Stones of Mother Earth.name: Stones of Mother Earth
Stones of Mother Earth.description: These earrings are made with diopside, and their name is taken from the reverence druids hold for this particular stone in high regard. The beautiful light green gem, set in gold, creates an allure of elegance and an air of nobility. The price reflects this appearance, aligning with the refined impression they leave.

Stool.name: Stool
Stool.description: A standard wooden stool used in many taverns is often repurposed as an improvised weapon in the event of a brawl.

Stopwatch.name: Stopwatch
Stopwatch.description: Mechanical stopwatches are powered by a mainspring, which must be wound up, usually by turning the knurled knob at the top of the stopwatch. They are primarily used to measure elapsed time in various fields such as sports, training, and science for activities like running laps or conducting experiments.

Strawberry.name: Strawberry
Strawberry.description: Strawberries are a favorite fruit among all folk as it is believed they bring happiness. In addition to being consumed fresh, strawberries can be made into jam, as well as dried to be used in cooked foods.

Strawberry Blakewell.name: Strawberry Blakewell
Strawberry Blakewell.description: The Strawberry Blakewell is a type of tart made with a shortcrust pastry shell layered with jam, frangipane, and a topping of flaked almonds and candied fruit. Although it is mostly associated with strawberries, other candied fruits such as cherries, kiwis, pears, and peaches can be used as well. This tart is a popular snack among people of all ages due to its sweet and fruity flavor.

Strudel.name: Strudel
Strudel.description: The strudel is a classic pastry, oblong in shape, with a fruit filling inside, such as apples, pears, peaches, berries, and many more. It can be topped with powdered sugar, sweet cocoa, or honey. This pastry is a quick favorite among people of all ages and pairs well with morning beverages, such as coffee or teas.

Sugar Beet.name: Sugar Beet
Sugar Beet.description: These types of beets are mainly cultivated by farmers, and with the help of herbalists turned into sugar.

Sugar Pumpkin.name: Sugar Pumpkin
Sugar Pumpkin.description: Sugar pumpkins are a type of winter squash recognized for their sweet flavor and firm, smooth, dense flesh, making them perfect for pumpkin pies and other baked goods like cookies and loaves of bread.

Sugarcane.name: Sugarcane
Sugarcane.description: Sugarcane, predominantly grown in tropical regions, is primarily cultivated for sugar production. Sugar mills extract raw sugar from freshly harvested cane, and 'mill-white' sugar is occasionally produced right after the initial extraction phase at these mills, often for local markets.

Sunberry.name: Sunberry
Sunberry.description: Or Wonderberries sometimes referred to as Nightshade. In the past, there had been rumors of a creature sharing the Nightshade name as well. These plants are of a universal type, Eggplants and Tomatoes are part of the same family of nightshade, as well as Tabacco and the Belladonna plant. However, when herbalists refer to Nightshade they mainly refer to a specific type called Sunberries. It is used in home remedies by the common folk.

Sunset Walk.name: Sunset Walk
Sunset Walk.description: Sunset Walk is a generic wine found in most general stores. It got the name, more of an advertising technique to induce the idea that prior to going for the evening walk, have a glass of wine, as it boosts blood flow, for a more healthier life. Most herbalists and alchemists vehemently disagree. It’s not fine wine, but it warms the chest and softens the day’s sharp edges.

Sushi.name: Sushi
Sushi.description: Sushi is made out of vinegared rice, usually seasoned with sugar and salt, combined with various ingredients like vegetables and meats, primarily seafood. It is commonly wrapped in dried seaweed and can be served either raw or cooked.

Sweet Bread.name: Sweet Bread
Sweet Bread.description: Sweet bread varies significantly in taste and appearance depending on the region. Some regions opt for cocoa, while others prefer fruit-based recipes. However, regardless of the specific type ordered, whether in taverns or bakeries, sweet bread is a popular choice for religious celebrations or events, as well as for those with a sweet tooth.

Sweetsop.name: Sweetsop
Sweetsop.description: It is commonly referred to as Sugar-Apple and is considered one of the most delicious, if not somewhat rare, fruits you can find. With its plump green scales, the sugar apple looks like a curled up pangolin. The sugar apple is usually consumed as a fresh dessert fruit, or used to make juice.

Tabasheer.name: Tabasheer
Tabasheer.description: Tabasheer is an opal-like type of stone found in the nodes of specific bamboo. This stone is not used for ornamentation but is valued by herbalists for medicinal purposes, aiding in the treatment of symptoms such as fevers, wounds, or uncontrollable vomiting, whether caused by arcane sources or otherwise.

Table.name: Table
Table.description: Standard tables are used to furnish both indoor and outdoor spaces of inns and taverns. They are usually made from planks for easy replacement and maintenance, providing surfaces for patrons to enjoy drinks and food.

Tablàh.name: Tablàh
Tablàh.description: The tablàh, commonly referred to as the goblet drum or chalice drum, and sometimes called dombek or tarabuka depending on the region, has a shape that resembles a large goblet. Made of wood with a thin leather membrane, this percussion instrument plays a vital role in many musical traditions, contributing a unique rhythm to them.

Taffeta.name: Taffeta
Taffeta.description: A plain woven fabric made from silk, dressmakers, and seamstress mainly use it in ball gowns, wedding dresses, and corsets but it is also used in interior decoration as curtains and wall covers.

Tambourine.name: Tambourine
Tambourine.description: The tambourine is a versatile percussion instrument featuring a wooden frame with pairs of small metal jingles known as zills. It can be played in many ways such as held in the hand, mounted on a stand, shaken to produce a lively sound, or struck sharply with the hand or a stick. Musicians can also use the tambourine attached to their leg or hip for added rhythm.

Tanners’ Bolt.name: Tanners’ Bolt
Tanners’ Bolt.description: Tanners' Bolt does refer to the end product that comes from a tannery. Tanning hide into leather involves a process that permanently alters the skin, making it more durable and less susceptible to decomposition and coloring due to age. The end product comes in a huge roll with several layers of leather, simply called a bolt.

Tannin Leather.name: Tannin Leather
Tannin Leather.description: Tannin refers to the specific form of tanning, using a specific type of bark to strengthen the leather, in some regions, simply known as vegetable tanning. Most leatherworkers attempt to avoid it as it is quite time consuming, however, nobility love it as they misunderstand it and believe that it is leather made out of vegetables, while in reality, only a specific bark is used in the tanning process.

Tanzanite.name: Tanzanite
Tanzanite.description: The Tanzanite gemstone, a type of zoisite, is known for its deep blue color and unique optical properties. It is one of the few gemstones that can display three different colors depending on the viewing angle. Tanzanite appears as a distinct blue when viewed from one direction and shifts to hues ranging from violet to red when viewed from other angles.

Tea.name: Tea
Tea.description: Tea comes in various types such as green, black, root, herbal, or fruity, each served with hot water to achieve different desired effects. Herbalists often recommend peppermint or chamomile tea for its calming effects, while ginger tea is favored for alleviating stomach ailments. Black tea serves as a popular substitute for coffee, while green or fruity teas are enjoyed as refreshing beverages. Regardless of the type or purpose, tea is widely consumed and in high demand.

Teak Log.name: Teak Log
Teak Log.description: The logs are typically harvested from tropical regions and are known for their durability and resistance to rot and decay. The logs are often used to create strong and sturdy structures, such as buildings, bridges, and fences, as well as furniture. The wood is also prized for its resistance to pests and insects, making it a popular choice for use in household items.

Teak Plank.name: Teak Plank
Teak Plank.description: Because Teak wood is resistant to rot and decay, as well as insects and other pests, it is a popular choice for outdoor applications, such as decks, patios, and fencing. Teak can also be used in the construction of ships and other watercraft, as it is resistant to water damage and warping.

Tektite.name: Tektite
Tektite.description: When rocks fall from the heavens and smash mountains, the small-sized rocks that are charred are called tektites. However, most alchemists are curious about the overall process at the moment of impact, as it turns the small rocks into glass. Tektite is mainly used as furniture ornamentation as its shade of blue is quite pleasant to the eye.

The Flirt.name: The Flirt
The Flirt.description: Russula Vesca, or The Flirt, is an edible mushroom, in fact, many people consider this to be one of the very finest wild mushrooms. The mushroom itself does come with a mild nutty flavor and could be eaten even raw, however, they do shine when they are served with meat dishes or stews.

The Forest.name: The Forest
The Forest.description: The Forest is a necklace crafted from copper and set with a zoisite implement. While copper is a relatively inexpensive material, the presence of the zoisite balances the value, resulting in a piece that has a surprisingly high price. Yet, because copper is somewhat fragile, these necklaces are often found in crowded places, having slipped from their wearers' necks after the copper has corroded.

The Last Veiled Widow.name: The Last Veiled Widow
The Last Veiled Widow.description: This highly acidic mushroom gets its name from the phosphorescent mesh that surrounds it. Compared to its more common counterpart, the Veiled Lady, the lethality of this specific mushroom is uncommon, as when ingested it turns to acid and starts consuming the unfortunate folk from the inside out, only leaving bones behind. A few months later, the bones give rise to more Veiled Widows.

The Sickener.name: The Sickener
The Sickener.description: The Sickener, or Vomiting Russula, is a mushroom that walks the line between danger and culinary delight. Its consumption can lead to nausea and vomiting, hence its grim nickname. Yet, some regions use it as a spice in traditional dishes like goulash, relying on careful preparation to neutralize its unpleasant properties.

Thimble.name: Thimble
Thimble.description: Resembling a small cap, typically made of metal or bone, the thimble is worn over the fingertip to safeguard it while pushing a needle through cloth during sewing. A cherished tool among tailors and leatherworkers, as it is indispensable in their toolset.

Thousand Yes.name: Thousand Yes
Thousand Yes.description: This book contains 500 pages, with the word "Yes" written repeatedly on both sides of every page. Many believe there is more to this book than what meets the eye, but no one has yet identified its true purpose. Holding the book gives an ominous, unsettling feeling, and staring into its pages for too long makes it seem as if the word itself begins to warp and shift. The only clue to its origin is the name of its author is a small note stating "One."

Thyme.name: Thyme
Thyme.description: Thyme is available in both fresh and dried forms. Although it's typically a summer-season herb, fresh greenhouse thyme can be found year-round. The fresh variety offers superior flavor but requires more careful handling, with a storage life usually not exceeding a week. However, it can be preserved for many months when frozen properly.

Ticks.name: Ticks
Ticks.description: Ticks are insects that latch onto passing animals and common folk to feed on their blood. They are found in tall grasses and wooded areas, waiting for a host to brush by. Everytime a herbalist has to handle an tick, as they are known carriers of diseases, it asks the farmers to check all livestock that they own as well.

Tiger Hide.name: Tiger Hide
Tiger Hide.description: Tiger Hide is a large piece of pelt coming from a quite an majestic beast, which has a tendency to be victorious against large hunting parties, making it a rare find at merchants. The creature can be mostly found in dense evergreen forests or deep jungles, finding one is usually not easy.

Tiger's Eye.name: Tiger's Eye
Tiger's Eye.description: One of the more common gemstones out there, used as a status symbol among commoners, as it comes in a combination of gold and black. Due to its high demand, depending on the region, it can be quite rare. In most superstitious groups the gemstone is assumed to repel undead and restless spirits.

Timed Explosive.name: Timed Explosive
Timed Explosive.description: Timed explosives are devices that detonate after a predetermined delay, often using a timer to trigger the explosion, giving just enough time to get out of harm's way. The delayed explosions allow fragmented rock to move before the next charge detonates, maximizing the blast's effectiveness and reducing vibrations that could damage the structure of the mines.

Timer.name: Timer
Timer.description: Usually associated with explosives, for situations where multiple explosions need to happen simultaneously, an amazing piece of engineering, whether for the demolition of a gate wall or a sturdy mine wall. The timer is a necessity for a planned chained reaction. However, it is also used in sporting events to provide a clear indication of a winner.

Timpani.name: Timpani
Timpani.description: Timpani, frequently referred to as kettledrums, are percussion instruments characterized by their striking sound. Played with specialized drumsticks known as mallets, held in pairs. Musicians often have a collection of timpani mallets on hand, as each mallet produces a unique timbre and sound. The variety enhances their role in orchestral music, where they provide a one-of-a-kind rhythmic experience.

Tin.name: Tin
Tin.description: Tin is usually combined with Copper, due to it being soft, to prevent its oxidation. Doesn't have many uses besides the preservation of metals.

Tiretaine.name: Tiretaine
Tiretaine.description: The Tiretaine cloth is made with a mix of wool and other fabrics, mainly used to create towels, rags, and commoner dresses, as it is cheap to manufacture and easy to mass produce.

Titanium.name: Titanium
Titanium.description: Titanium is an incredible metal. It is really expensive and rare, but it also has some amazing strengthening properties that make it one of the strongest metals around! When forged into weapons and armor by the most famous blacksmiths throughout the realm, this precious silver-gray metal is said to be near indestructible, not to mention incredibly light yet stronger than steel, making it the perfect material for crafting weapons and armor.

To-do list.name: To-do list
To-do list.description:
Basic list of things made by a commoner.

  1. Fetch water frum tha well ‘fore sun gets too high

  2. Check on the goats, make sure that gray one ain’t wandered off again

  3. Fix that busted fence post near tha turnip patch

  4. Go to market, see if Ol’ Markla still got flour what don’t got bugs in it

  5. Patch Pa’s boots, if I can find where the I put the needle

  6. Chop more firewood, cause it’s still cold an I don’t trust that sky none

  7. Say prayers so the crops don’t rot this year like last

  8. Scrub them rags what got blood on ‘em from the hog birthing

  9. Don’t forget to ask Jorren if he seen them bandits near the crossroads

  10. Feed the chickens, then make sure none got took by foxes again

Toadstool.name: Toadstool
Toadstool.description: It usually has a dotted red cap and is assumed to be poisonous. If eaten it can cause serious illness and on occasion death. Harvested by gatherers and used by alchemists in creating poisons or antidotes.

Tomato.name: Tomato
Tomato.description: They come in multiple colors ranging from green to white, to yellow to red. Green tomatoes are usually stored over the winter with pickled cucumbers, as they have a very specific taste. The Red sweet, tangy tomatoes are delicious in all sorts of savory dishes, making it a must-have for most commoners and tavern keeps.

Tombak.name: Tombak
Tombak.description: Tombak is an alloy of copper and zinc used to imitate gold in cheap jewelry and for gilding. It is a cheap malleable alloy mainly used for medals, ornament, decoration and other ornamental uses. Yet the most nefarious of folk tend to purchase it in bulk to sell it at a premium as gold.

Topaz.name: Topaz
Topaz.description: Comes in many colors, one of the most common ones, is light blue, however, the most prized one is a bright yellow also known as Imperial Topaz. Highly valued by nobility as they usually are offered as gifts at state gatherings. The gems are cut only by the most skilled master gem cutters.

Tourmaline.name: Tourmaline
Tourmaline.description: It is one of the most prized minerals, and its fine crystals can be among the most beautiful examples in the mineral kingdom. Instead of being faceted, many fine Tourmaline crystals are preserved for their beauty. It is also believed that they can absorb any spell cast upon them, and convert it into lightning.

Toy Horse.name: Toy Horse
Toy Horse.description: The toy horse provides a sense of adventure for young children, crafted primarily from wood and often accompanied by wooden toy swords and shields. It sparks the imagination and is a must for the new aspiring adventurers.

Training Dummy.name: Training Dummy
Training Dummy.description: While quite rare and often quickly replaced by living partners, training dummies serve the purpose of training new combatants in body positions and strike techniques. Due to their fragility and tendency to break with minimal use, they are rare.

Transport Cage.name: Transport Cage
Transport Cage.description: This wooden cage is designed for the easy transportation of small livestock, such as hens, chickens, and small hares, facilitating their movement to and from local markets with ease.

Transport Shackles.name: Transport Shackles
Transport Shackles.description: These shackles, made from iron or steel, like their counterparts and intended for easy mass production, function similar to pillories. They are typically designed to link several sets of shackles in a daisy chain to facilitate the transport of prisoners between locations.

Travel Horse.name: Travel Horse
Travel Horse.description: A riding horse, or a saddle horse, is a horse used by mounted riders for recreation or transportation. It offers freedom, and movement, and enables some amazing feats of athleticism. There is a total thrill in galloping across an open field, in tune with your mount.

Truffle.name: Truffle
Truffle.description: The truffle is a subterranean mushroom, they are often located with the help of hogs possessing a refined sense of smell. Due to their high price and strong aroma, truffles are used sparingly in gourmet cooking. Supplies are available commercially as unadulterated fresh produce or preserved, typically in a light brine. Since their volatile aromas dissipate quickly when heated, truffles are generally served raw and shaved over warm, simple dishes to highlight their unique flavor.

Tulip.name: Tulip
Tulip.description: Tulips once triggered a major economic crisis, known as "tulip mania," because of their striking appearance, popularity, and limited availability. Since they required a specific climate and harvest cycle, they became luxury goods. After the bubble burst, tulips eventually became accessible at a more reasonable price, accessible to every commoner.

Tuna Fish.name: Tuna Fish
Tuna Fish.description: The tuna is a saltwater fish, commonly found in warmer waters across the realms. It is widely harvested from the seas and oceans, with catches often reaching hundreds of pounds or more per fish, making it a valuable resource in many regions.

Tungsten Ingot.name: Tungsten Ingot
Tungsten Ingot.description: Tungsten Ingots are a rare product, crafted only by experienced blacksmiths using some of the hottest smelters. The pure Tungsten Ingot’s primary use lies in alchemical research, particularly in the development of new, powerful acids capable of dissolving everything. Due to their rarity and the immense difficulty in forging them, locating a properly refined one is akin to finding a needle in a haystack.

Tungsten Rod.name: Tungsten Rod
Tungsten Rod.description: Tungsten, sometimes referred to as "Wolfram", is one of the heaviest metals used in any form of crafting. Due to its heavy nature and tough molding, it is primarily used in alloying with softer metals, such as Rhenium or Aluminum all to enhance their durability and shelf life. Another use of tungsten is in the creation of combat battering rams, from which it derives its name.

Turnip.name: Turnip
Turnip.description: Turnips are a favorite for farmers as they do not require a long growing season.  The roots are cooked and served whole or mashed and are used in stews. They can also be used as fodder for cattle.

Turqoise.name: Turqoise
Turqoise.description: Carved or used as ornaments, turquoise has been considered a precious gem throughout history. Found in old tombs in the form of small animal statuettes or as an ornaments on doors for royalty. It is a common good luck charm, used by horsemen and traders while traveling to ward off any ambushes or missteps in their future travels.

Undersea Remains.name: Undersea Remains
Undersea Remains.description: These bones are so rare, that nobody can identify them clearly. Some state that they belong to unseen horrors from different realms, or of an ancient form of fish. These are highly valued by most collectors due to their complex retrieval process.

Utility Acid.name: Utility Acid
Utility Acid.description: A regular strong acid, strong enough to corrode iron and bronze, however, not strong enough to dissolve stronger metals. It is usually a must-have for a locksmith, as it is quite efficient against most forms of locks and tends to save some money in the long term, given how regular iron pliers get damaged with repeated use.

Vanadium.name: Vanadium
Vanadium.description: Vanadium is a desired metal throughout the realms, and for very good reason. It is insanely rare and has a deep, green-gray luster that shines in the light. Some blacksmiths and alchemists can imbue vanadium with magical properties, making it even more valuable. Vanadium is very light yet stronger than steel and is speculated that it can absorb and store magical energy.

Variscite.name: Variscite
Variscite.description: Variscite, resembling Jade in color, is commonly used as a decorative element in clothing. According to belief, it possesses toxic properties harmful to nocturnal creatures if introduced through wounds or ingestion.

Vegetable Box.name: Vegetable Box
Vegetable Box.description: The box is designed for storing and transporting vegetables and fruits. Its stackable design makes it quite convenient for easy transport.

Vegetable Soup.name: Vegetable Soup
Vegetable Soup.description: Vegetable soups are typically crafted from locally available ingredients. Potatoes, squash, beans, and a variety of herbs such as dill, thyme, parsley, and tomatoes are commonly incorporated, providing a unique taste to each region's variation. In some areas, fruits are also added to lend a more exotic flavor.

Velvet.name: Velvet
Velvet.description: One of the most well known materials. It is woven on special types of looms that have a distinct way of seaming the cloth together. Velvet is often associated with nobility, however, in more recent times it got replaced with Cashmere wool.

Vermilion Snapper.name: Vermilion Snapper
Vermilion Snapper.description: Vermilion Snapper is a relatively large fish, typically caught by bottom fishing with live bait, such as squid or shrimp. The best time to catch Vermilion Snapper is between early summer and late fall when they are found over hard bottoms and reefs.

Vertebrae.name: Vertebrae
Vertebrae.description: Vertebrae are the multiple individual bones that interlock with each other to form the spinal column of most creatures. The most crafty craftsmen can create either flexible tools, like sturdy hook lines that can hold multiple creatures, or advanced weaponry, like bone whips that can do heavy damage to everything they touch.

Vertugal.name: Vertugal
Vertugal.description:
"Some say that the forest spirits don't like it when you cut these trees. As time has passed, more and more sightings of these beings have been made, taking the shape of different woodland creatures, from cats to foxes, deer to bears. If you notice one and you plan to bring harm to the forest, you won't be in this realm for long."

A type of soft, light-colored wood with a straight grain is commonly used in pulpwood and paper production. This wood is popular in the printing industry, as it is lightweight and easy to work with. It can also be used in combination with fabric, such as cotton, or animal leather, to create parchment or other paper products.

Vial of the Forgotten.name: Vial of the Forgotten
Vial of the Forgotten.description: This mysterious concoction is said to forge a powerful connection between the living and the dead. When consumed, the drinker gains the ability to interact with loved ones who have passed on or to gain insights from the spirits of the past. However, once consumed, this potion never wears off, slowly draining the sanity of those who dare to connect with the afterlife. From the few records that exist on this potion, it is also stated that you can see your own ghost, even while alive, making it uncertain if the potion is lethal.

Violet Garnet.name: Violet Garnet
Violet Garnet.description: Or Rhodolite, is mainly used by whitesmiths, jewelers, gaffers, and sometimes even blacksmiths for ornamentation purposes. In some cultures and faiths, garnets were thought to be the solidified blood of the religion's specific divine avatar.

Wall Meat.name: Wall Meat
Wall Meat.description: Wall Meat, harvested from the Kurnarac, is a prized delicacy among the subterranean folk, due to the long and laborious process of planting and harvesting it. Despite its name, Wall Meat is not actual meat but a type of mushroom with a tough, hard exterior. Its preparation is simple but can be off-putting to those unaccustomed to underground cuisine, as it has a strong, mold-like odor from its lengthy time spent in the subterranean environment. Only those with a robust constitution are fit to cook it. Once prepared, however, it has a rich flavor, blending the best qualities of tender beef and sautéed mushrooms.

Walnut.name: Walnut
Walnut.description: Harvested from the walnut tree, they can be used in several recipes for an added taste. Such as Sprinkled on salads, added to sauces, created dehydrated fruits, added on bakery products, and many more other culinary uses but it also can be eaten raw.

Walnut Log.name: Walnut Log
Walnut Log.description: Walnut wood is commonly used for furniture, flooring, cabinetry, and decorative items due to its rich color and workability. The leaves can be used for sunburns, itching as well, and dandruff, when processed by the herbalists in poultrices.

Walnut Lumber.name: Walnut Lumber
Walnut Lumber.description: Once harvested, walnut lumber is commonly used for furniture, flooring, cabinetry, and decorative items due to its rich color and workability. and due to it being a low price, it is in high demand by most carpenters and woodworkers.

Wardrobe.name: Wardrobe
Wardrobe.description: Due to the considerable amount of materials involved, wardrobes are generally made to order by carpenters in smaller towns or villages.

Watcher Cake.name: Watcher Cake
Watcher Cake.description: Crafted with a topping that's as rare as it is enigmatic, sourced mainly from the quests or missions of adventurers. This cake is rumored to slow down the aging process by half for the year following consumption. However, such rumors have never been confirmed.

Watchful Gaze.name: Watchful Gaze
Watchful Gaze.description: Watchful Gaze is a cocktail with sweetened gelatin shaped to resemble an eye. It is primarily cooled vodka, however, the sugar from the gelatin and the rendered fat from the gelatin, it does provide a specific, quite famous, taste. Despite its eerie aesthetic, the cocktail is simple to make and relatively cheap, due to its minimal ingredient list.

Water Opal.name: Water Opal
Water Opal.description: Water Opal, sometimes referred to as jelly opal, is a precious opal known for its transparent appearance and absence of body color. Unlike typical opals, water opals have a unique property of seemingly dissipating arcane spells.

Watermelon.name: Watermelon
Watermelon.description: Watermelon is a sweet, commonly consumed summer fruit, usually, as fresh slices, diced in mixed fruit salads, or as juice. Watermelon juice can be blended with other fruit juices or made into wine.

Waxed Thread.name: Waxed Thread
Waxed Thread.description: Tiger Hide is a large piece of pelt coming from a quite an majestic beast, which has a tendency to be victorious against large hunting parties, making it a rare find at merchants. The creature can be mostly found in dense evergreen forests or deep jungles, finding one is usually not easy.

Weakfish.name: Weakfish
Weakfish.description: Weakfish are known for their delicious taste and spirited fight. They migrate inshore during the warmer months to spawn and thrive in estuarine and coastal waters. Primarily used in cooking due to its ease of preparation, Weakfish is commonly baked or fried. Alternatively, its delicate texture makes it an excellent option for fish tacos or fish and potato chips.

Wheel of Cheese.name: Wheel of Cheese
Wheel of Cheese.description: While some may argue that what beats a slice of cheese, in most scenarios, the answer is indeed a wheel of cheese, and fortunately, most markets and taverns offer it for sale.

Where to Find Veins - A Prospector's Gui.name: Where to Find Veins - A Prospector's Guide to Ore Finding
Where to Find Veins - A Prospector's Gui.description: Detailed guide on the versatility of minerals and how they absorb properties from their surroundings. The book provides extensive information on how to quickly identify minerals by color once found in a cave or mine system. It includes details such as how hematite, while considered a lesser gem, can be processed to extract iron ore, and how bauxite can similarly be refined to produce aluminum. Miners, alchemists, and artisans alike also review this guide to refine their understanding of valuable mineral resources and their practical applications and composition.

White Beans.name: White Beans
White Beans.description: White beans are known for their pale color and starchy texture. Multiple types exist in various shapes and sizes, often bearing different names depending on the region. Though commonly used interchangeably in cooking, each variety offers a distinct size, form, and taste.

White Gold.name: White Gold
White Gold.description: White gold, an alloy of gold and silver, should not be mistaken for platinum. Known as gray gold in some regions, it is highly valued by the nobility for its high price and pristine silver look in their jewelry.

White Grub.name: White Grub
White Grub.description: White Grubs are the larvae form of multiple beetles, found just beneath the soil. They feed on the roots of grasses and plants, causing dead patches in pastures and gardens. Though a bane to most farms, anglers value them as exceptionally effective bait.

White Pearl.name: White Pearl
White Pearl.description: These specific Pearls are generally found in saltwater and are mostly sought after by royalty and nobility due to their rarity. The rarest ones, usually the size of someone's head are used in crystal balls, however, they mustn't have any imperfections.

White Radish.name: White Radish
White Radish.description: Quite often it is referred to as the winter radish due to its clear white color very similar to snow. The white radish works well in salads and slaws, or as a side dish for summer picnics, and also works well stir-fried with meat.

Whole Poultry.name: Whole Poultry
Whole Poultry.description: Many taverns offer a variety of stuffed poultry dishes, ideal for both special events and those seeking to share a hearty platter. These dishes are typically accompanied by sides such as roasted potatoes or greens, catering to diverse tastes.

Wild Mint.name: Wild Mint
Wild Mint.description: The leaves are a popular choice to garnish some beverages and desserts. Gatherers farm huge quantities of Wild Mint as they can also be made into teas to treat colds and to aid digestion.

Wine.name: Wine
Wine.description: While grape wine remains the most common variety, there are also other variants available, including blueberry, nettle, apple, elderberry, and red currant wines. Prices for these wines can vary significantly based on the fruit used and its age.

Winter Kept Pelt.name: Winter Kept Pelt
Winter Kept Pelt.description: The preferred type of pelt used to manufacture the Far North leather armor and clothing provides very good insulation from the elements. While in high demand in the colder climates, this specific type of pelt is outright detested by leatherworkers who have ever come across it, as without the right tools, they are close to impossible to cut.

Witches Brew.name: Witches Brew
Witches Brew.description: Younglings adore it, and even some of the older folk take a mug for nostalgia, sometimes with a drop of spiced brandy slipped in by a cheeky tavern keeper. There are stories tied to it. Some say if you stir your cup thrice under the harvest moon you’ll glimpse the face of your future love in the foam. I tried once in Harthen Hollow. All I got was a sticky nose and a laugh from the brewer’s daughter who had been watching me the whole time. Maybe that counts as magic enough.

Witherite.name: Witherite
Witherite.description: Witherite is a distinctive gemstone known for its requirement of a specific mount. Whether used in jewelry, armor, or any decorative item, it must be mounted on an electrum piece, a gold and silver alloy, otherwise, it risks becoming dislodged.

Wolf Bane's Leaves.name: Wolf Bane's Leaves
Wolf Bane's Leaves.description: Referred to as Belladonna, it is usually believed to be of aid when communing with deities, as it is known that it can bring forth a strong connection to any plane. Alchemists usually harvest it with utmost caution as it is used in the creation of one of the deadliest plant-derived poisons on the market. Herbalists use it as a cure for early forms of Lycanthropy and as a treatment to manage and delay the more advanced stages of the disease.

Wolf Jaw Tongs.name: Wolf Jaw Tongs
Wolf Jaw Tongs.description: Considered the most universal tongs for general work of varying sizes, wolf jaw tongs feature smooth, narrow jaws on top with a V-notch on the inside running its length. This makes them one of the most essential tools in the tool belt of any blacksmith.

Wolfsbane Retreat.name: Wolfsbane Retreat
Wolfsbane Retreat.description: This potion is known to keep the Lycanthrope transformation at bay. The Wolf Bane leaves need to be fresh and be ground to a cloud of fine dust, then combined with a couple of Belladonna fruits and some other reagents. Anyone who is not a Lycanthrope will meet his death at the first drop of it on his tongue. If consumed by a Lycanthrope that was just bitten, it is speculated it can fully cure it. When it is consumed at the start of the evening of the full moon it can delay the transformation to the next full moon.

Wood Lily.name: Wood Lily
Wood Lily.description: Gathered from mountainous regions, they are said to be quite toxic for small home animals, however, herbalists use their bulbs crushed on swellings and bruises, or provide them as medicinal teas for patients who complain of stomachaches or coughs and fevers.

Wooden Bowl.name: Wooden Bowl
Wooden Bowl.description: Carved from hardwoods, wooden bowls are both aesthetically pleasing and practical, known for their heat retention and easy handling. Nevertheless, their porous nature can complicate cleaning and maintenance, necessitating special care.

Wooden Ladle.name: Wooden Ladle
Wooden Ladle.description: The ladle plays a crucial role in most kitchens. Wooden ladles are specifically used with expensive or cast-iron pots to prevent scratching and extend their lifespan.

Wooden Mannequin.name: Wooden Mannequin
Wooden Mannequin.description: Wooden mannequins, also known as laymen or lay figures, have many uses, ranging from artists to leatherworkers. Artists utilize these mannequins as molds for their sculptures, applying a layer of gypsum that is later removed to reveal the final form. Meanwhile, leatherworkers shape leather around these figures to craft hide armor and other equipment tailored to fit a humanoid form.

Wooden Ornamentation.name: Wooden Ornamentation
Wooden Ornamentation.description: In some regions, common folk enjoy extensive ornamentation on their houses, ships, and even fences. Though it tends to be an expensive project, the end result is visually appealing for generations to come.
Wooden Ornamentation.gmNote: Alternative icons exist in the module's folder

Wooden Pipes.name: Wooden Pipes
Wooden Pipes.description: Wooden pipes, or tobacco pipes, are specifically designed for smoking tobacco and herbs. They are typically constructed from strong, hardwoods like briar or corn cob, each offering benefits such as durability and a unique smoking flavor.

Wooden Wheel.name: Wooden Wheel
Wooden Wheel.description: The wheel is a vital invention with widespread applications in society. It is used as a main component in carts, wagons, and carriages, and it is also been used in executions, such as with the breaking wheel. Its importance is evident in various aspects of a commoner's life.

Wool.name: Wool
Wool.description: A textile fabric that is obtained from farm animals, mainly sheep, and is primarily used for clothing. In addition to that, it is also used for blankets, saddle cloths for cavalry, carpeting, and on rare occasions even a soil fertilizer.

Worm.name: Worm
Worm.description: Worms are an common sight in healthy soil, mainly after heavy rains. They consume decaying roots making them a good sight, and a hope of good harvest, in any garden or farm. They are also widely used by commoners and fishermen as reliable bait for fishing.

Wulfenite.name: Wulfenite
Wulfenite.description: Wulfenite is exceptionally soft and prone to breaking due to its flat, rectangular crystals. Despite this, its vibrant red and orange hues are captivating, leading gem cutters to produce small, sparkling, faceted gems ideal for settings with minimal handling, like inlays on furniture and royal displays.

Yam.name: Yam
Yam.description: The process of harvesting yams is physically demanding and labor-intensive, necessitating the use of wooden tools to protect the crop. Some farmers adopt staking and mixed cropping methods, which can complicate the harvesting process. Yams are utilized in diverse culinary preparations, such as flour or whole vegetable pieces for salads or stews.

Yellowfin Tuna.name: Yellowfin Tuna
Yellowfin Tuna.description: Yellowfin tuna is a large and powerful oceanic fish distinguished by its glowing yellow fins and sleek, torpedo-shaped body built for speed and endurance, making it a most difficult catch. Found mostly in warm tropical waters near secluded islands, it demands the use of specially equipped fishing boats with trolleys to handle its immense weight.

Zamac.name: Zamac
Zamac.description: Zamac is a zinc-based alloy primarily used in jewelry, but it is also utilized for making tools, bolts, and hinges. It is particularly favored in applications where paint is used, as dyes adhere exceptionally well to it.

Zinc.name: Zinc
Zinc.description: Zinc is a rare, shimmering metal that is known for its ability to protect against the elements. It has a soft, silver color that glimmers in the light.  It is often used to coat other metals, such as iron or steel, to protect them from rust and decay. In ancient times, it was believed to have magical properties and was used in the crafting of powerful talismans and amulets, even magical mirrors.

Zircon.name: Zircon
Zircon.description: Zircon is a gemstone of many colors. There is also a transparent variant of it very similar to a diamond, which is why its usually used as a cheaper alternative to it. Anyone without knowledge of gemstones can be easily fooled into believing that the stone is more expensive than its actually is.

Zither.name: Zither
Zither.description: The zither is an instrument that exists in various shapes and sizes, with the defining characteristic of being a plucked instrument. Numerous regional variations can be found worldwide. In some cultures, the zither is celebrated as an all-rounded instrument, valued for its beautiful and resonant sound. This instrument is not only a staple in music but is also well-regarded in some religious settings, where its beautiful sound enhances choir performances.

Zoisite.name: Zoisite
Zoisite.description: This particular gem can be found in a variety of colors, including green, brown, pink, and black. These gems are particularly favored by people who lead secluded lives, as they are believed to ward off negative thoughts and emotions, whether they are caused by magic or other means. They are said to promote a sense of calm when worn. These gems are in high demand among hermits, monks, and common folk who live in remote areas.

Zombie.name: Zombie
Zombie.description: Zombie is an exotic cocktail made of fruit juices, such as lime and grapefruit juice, cynnamon syrup, liqueurs, and three different types of rum. Usually served with catchy frazes like "Let's make the dead walk and talk." or "Craving action? Soon you’ll be staring through the eyes of the undead!"

Zucchini.name: Zucchini
Zucchini.description: Zucchini is usually served cooked and can be prepared using a variety of techniques. These include steaming, boiling, grilling, stuffing and baking, barbecuing, frying, or incorporating it into soufflés and stir-fries.
